PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth: that the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill:
1. Offer nothing more than is already available under law,
2. deny some Human Rights and do not include others,
3. give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend several Acts, being the Health Insurance Act 1973, the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, the National Health Act 1953, the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 and the Tuberculosis Act 1948. The major amendments proposed by this Bill are contained in Part II relating to the provision of pathology services. These amendments are designed to improve arrangements for the payment of Medicare benefits for pathology services. As a result of findings by the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts in its Report (number 236) on Medical Fraud and Overservicing-Pathology, there has been serious public concern about improper practices in the pathology industry. The amendments in Part II of this Bill are designed to introduce significant new controls over the provision of pathology services and thus greatly reduce the capacity for fraud or overservicing in the pathology industry.
The Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee raised a number of particular areas of concern about the provision of pathology services. The Committee said, in part, that:
the Medicare Benefit Schedule was too complex and it encouraged pathologists to perform more tests than were necessary;
payment was too high for many tests made simple by the introduction of modern laboratory equipment;
the prospect of large profits had attracted ``entrepreneurial pathology'';
pathology groups were providing ``inducements'' to doctors to order more services than were necessary;

pathology groups were encouraging doctors to order unnecessary tests by other means-such as providing request form pads which set out combinations of tests which the laboratories were able to perform automatically;
many laboratories were routinely adding to their incomes by performing additional tests not ordered by referring doctors;
doctors were found to have financial interests in laboratories which performed their tests.

The amendments in Part II of the Bill before the Senate today are designed to meet these concerns and represent the results of an extensive review by the Department of Health and the Health Insurance Commission of the existing arrangements covering the provision of pathology services.

Statistics available to the Department of Health show that the number and cost of pathology services have risen sharply in recent years. An estimated 15% of total Commonwealth spending on Medicare benefits is on pathology. In 1984/85 claims processed for Medicare benefits payments totalled $346 million out of a total outlay of $2,280 million. Between 1979 and 1985 there was a 69% increase in pathology services as services rose from 13 million to 22 million over this period.
The Government has therefore decided to introduce a package of measures which will affect the provision of pathology services under the current Medicare benefit arrangements.

There are at least two fees for most services in the pathology section of the Medicare Benefits Schedule. The circumstances in which the service is performed by an approved pathology practitioner outside a public hospital determines whether the higher or lower fee applies:
the higher fee (SP) Specialist Pathology applies when the service is performed by a specialist patho-logist; and

the lower fee (OP) Other Pathology (75% of the specialist fee) otherwise applies. It also applies where a specialist pathologist decides that additional tests are necessary without consulting the referring doctor, and in a number of other circumstances.

A lower fee (HP) Hospital Pathology (generally about 50% of the specialist fee) applies to a small number (18) of very common tests performed in public laboratories for private patients in public hospitals. Therefore for those 18 tests there are three levels of fees.

However, there has been a substantial shift to patient billing at the specialist rate of benefit in recent years. The Parliamentary Accounts Committee noted that the top 25 pathology groups bill virtually all their pathology at the specialist rate, the percentage varying between 94.6% and 99.9%. In addition, during the period 1982/3 to 1984/5 the number of services billed at the specialist rate increased by 41.9% while during the same period the number of services billed at the (OP) Other Patho-logy and (HP) Hospital Pathology rates fell by -18.2% and -29.1% respectively.

But the fact is, the increasing volume of services being billed at the highest rate is not being matched by an increasing professional input by specialist pathologists. In fact, the Parliamentary Accounts Committee pointed out:

``The great majority of tests being paid at the highest (specialist) level of benefit are not-and do not have to be-done by a a specialist pathologist but are being carried out by medical scientists/technologists. This can amount to payment of an unwarranted premium in some cases and further encourage overservicing. Virtually all the pathology performed by the top 25 groups is done at the highest (specialist) rate, which is 33% higher than the rate chargeable where a medical practitioner other than a specialist pathologist is employed.

It added that there were data showing that at the time they were contacted by a PAC member, few of the top 25 pathology groups in Australia had many full-time specialist pathologists on staff. Part-time specialist pathologists were associated with 60% of them.
Thus the specialist fees for those 18 pathology items appear too high, because the professional premium is far more than can be justified by the specialist's professional input.

There is also evidence that the fees for the 18 tests, for which there is currently an HP rate, are too high. The costs for some laboratories involved in undertaking these tests is covered by the HP fee which is currently only 50% of the Specialist rate. This means that there is an excessive profit component where they are billed at the Specialist rate.

In addition, by international comparison, the current specialist rates for these 18 tests are unreasonably high. When one examines the New Zealand fees for pathology tests, they are considerably less than the Australian fees-sometimes less than 50% of their Australian equivalent. After allowing for the difference in currency valuation, the New Zealand fees fall to an even smaller percentage of the Australian fees.

The Government has therefore decided it will reduce the SP rate to the current OP rate for those 18 items. In addition the new OP rate will be 75% of the New SP rate. The HP rate will disappear and services previously charged at this level will now be charged at the new OP rate. The 18 tests involved are generally:
high volume and mainly automated;
highly profitable because fees have not been adjusted downwards because of more productive technology;
generally involve minimum specialist input; and
the proposal would maintain the specialist premium but at a lower level and save an estimated $47M pa while involving a 12 1/2% rise in HP fees ($1M) for public hospital pathology services.
The proposal outlined will have the effect of:
reducing fees for a small number of commonly performed automated tests;
having the greatest impact on laboratories that concentrate on tests with high profits;
removing a significant financial incentive to excessive servicing and other abuses; and
simplifying the Schedule by reducing the number of rates for the 18 tests from three to two.

The Government recognises that the proposed fee reductions will have an impact on the profitability of all private laboratories which render these tests. That is to say, whilst commercially oriented laboratories will be hardest hit, the effects of the reduced fees will also be felt by reputable laboratories. However, I need to emphasise that the cost structure for private pathology is much higher than it needs to be. This is because it reflects high competition/expansion cost components which, in turn, is a clear indication of the excessive profit margin in pathology fees. Typically, courier and specimen collection fees account for 25-30 percent of total costs. There is ample scope to reduce expenditure in this area. Overall the Government is confident that private pathologists can satisfactorily rationalise their operations to absorb the effect of the reduced fees in such a way that it does not adversely impact on the delivery of an adequate and professional standard of service.
It is also proposed to remove Part 7 (Pathology) from the existing Medicare Benefits Schedule and establish a separate new Schedule for pathology items.
The items to be covered in this new Schedule are those contained in Schedule 1 to this Bill. It is intended that the Schedule will come into operation on 1 August 1986.

The Bill also provides for the establishment of a Pathology Services Advisory Committee to oversight movements within the new Schedule. The functions of the Committee are to review pathology items and fee levels, to consider related matters and make recommendations to the Minister for Health on such matters. The Minister may determine principles to be applied in the performance of the Committee's functions-the Minister has undertaken to consult the Australian Medical Association and the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia on the principles.

While the Bill provides for the Minister to refer matters to the Committee, which the Committee must consider and make recommendations on to the Minister, it does not limit the capacity of appropriate bodies to raise matters with the Committee. However, in such cases the Committee will decide whether or not it is appropriate to consider the matter.

The proposed Committee will consist of 7 members: the Chairperson, a Deputy President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, three members appointed by the Minister for Health after consultation with the Australian Medical Association and the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia and three others members.

The AMA or College nominees will not be restricted from being involved in their own Association or College activities or discussing matters with their respective bodies. Matters of confidentiality will basically be a matter for consideration by the Committee. When established, it is proposed that the first task of the Committee will be to review the current level of pathology fees and the appropriateness of pathology items.

This decision by the Government means that from 1 August 1986 pathology items will no longer be subject to medical fee inquiries which has been the case for a number of years. In making this decision the Government considers that the method of updating pathology fees through fee inquiries is inappropriate and fails to take into account productivity changes in the delivery of pathology services. In addition the Medicare Benefits Schedule as currently structured is inflexible both in responding to new technology and the deletion of obsolete tests with regard to pathology services.

The functions of the proposed Committee will allow a more rapid and flexible approach to a wide range of fee-related matters including relativity of Schedule items, the value of items and additions to and deletions from the pathology schedule, than is the case under the current arrangement.

In conjunction with the reduction in certain pathology fees as already outlined, clause 10 of the Bill provides that the number of self-determined tests that pathologists will be allowed to perform is to be limited. These tests will be determined by the Minister for Health in consultation with the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia. The Royal College of Pathologists support this measure as the College believes that currently self-determined tests could be a source of abuse by some laboratories. The self-determined test agreed to between the Minister and the College will continue to attract Medicare benefits at the (OP) Other Pathology benefit rate.

In addition, the Parliamentary Accounts Committee commented that certain minor procedures, such as the collection of blood for pathology testing, should not attract separate Medicare benefits when they are performed in association with a consultation. It was considered that a separate item provided inappropriate financial incentives which led to the ordering of unnecessary or excessive pathology tests. For these reasons the Government has decided to remove Item 955 which deals with venepuncture and the collection of blood for forwarding to a pathologist from the Medicare Benefits Schedule. The recent increase in fees for general practitioner attendance items also supports this approach.

Current legislation provides that request forms held by pathologists are to be produced within 14 days of a request. The Bill provides that, in future, request forms held by pathologists will be required to be produced to officers of the Health Insurance Commission by the end of the day following the making of such a request. A further proposal contained in the Bill is that request forms issued by the pathology laboratories for use by referring doctors are to be approved by the Health Insurance Commission. It is not intended to impose an `approved form' on laboratories but continued approval of forms by the Commission will ensure that any encouragement to medical practitioners to order inappropriate tests should be removed.
This proposal should not place undue administrative burdens on the pathologist given that laboratories will continue to be required to keep such requests for 18 months.

Advice has been received by the Department of Health that difficulties in the interpretation of section 129aa of the Health Insurance Act have contributed to the lack of success in bringing prosecutions against persons believed to have induced practitioners to order inappropriate tests. The amendments made by clause 47 of the Bill are designed to clarify the provision and also to render it a more effective deterrent to the practice of splitting the amounts of medicare benefit payable in respect of pathology services between the pathology practitioner rendering the services and the practitioner requesting them.

In recognising that medical practitioners are often encouraged to request more tests than may be required by the tactics of large laboratories and that practitioners are not always aware of costs of tests or the complex details of laboratory practice, the Government has decided to provide $100,000 per annum for each of the next three financial years to promote an education program directed primarily at medical interns and practitioners. The main aim of the program is to encourage the more appropriate use of pathology services by practitioners. The program would include, for example, assistance to the Royal College of Pathologists and the Royal College of General Practitioners in the development and distribution of educational material to medical practitioners in the community and teaching/seminar programs for medical interns.

Under the existing arrangements for the payment of Medicare benefits for pathology services, benefits are only paid where the services are performed by an approved pathology practitioner who is approved for such purposes by the Department of Health. In response to criticism of the administration of this scheme by the Public Accounts Committee, the Government has decided to completely revamp the existing scheme to greatly improve its effectiveness.

The main criticisms of the existing scheme by the Public Accounts Committee were that any person or organisation could apply and be approved as an approved pathology practitioner and there is no requirement that tests be performed in an accredited laboratory. In addition, there is often a nexus between the requesting doctor and laboratories which raises the possibility of overservicing. The Committee was also concerned that provisions of the scheme, particularly the current undertaking signed by the practitioner, were not being enforced and was generally of the view that the scheme is open ended and lacks an effective review mechanism.

The Bill proposes to change the existing scheme so that only medical practitioners (and the currently approved small number of medical laboratory scientists) will be eligible for approved pathology practitioner status, and approvals will be subject to annual review. Only natural persons can be approved pathology practitioners, a new scheme is introduced for approval of pathology companies, and there is to be greater emphasis upon closer personal supervision by the approved pathology practitioner of the pathology services rendered. Both approved pathology practitioners and approved pathology authorities will be required to sign undertakings. Breaches of these undertakings can be referred by the Minister to the Medicare Participation Review Committees for investigation and determination. These Committees will also be able to investigate cases of excessive pathology servicing either by the practitioner or authority or the initiating practitioner.

The existing legislation provides for the making of guidelines to be applied by these Committees in respect of the making of determinations. Under the new arrangements the guidelines will include provision for the Committees, before commencing an inquiry into a breach of an undertaking involving overservicing, to get a report from a specialist body which it sets up to examine the question of fact, namely whether excessive services were provided.

Approved pathology practitioners will be permitted to enter contractual arrangements with service laboratories where they do not wish to own, operate or manage their own laboratory. The conditions which apply to approved pathology authorities will also apply to these arrangements.

The Bill also introduces a system of accreditation of pathology laboratories. Services rendered by or on behalf of approved pathology practitioners are to be rendered in an accredited pathology laboratory (being services of a kind for which the laboratory is accredited) and under their direct supervision.

Under the existing approved pathology practitioner scheme, tests are often performed in laboratories not operated by such a practitioner, and approved pathology practitioners often lend their name to bills for services which are not adequately supervised. These practices will cease under the new arrangements.

The Minister for Health will have power to refuse applications for approved pathology practitioner or approved pathology authority status and there will a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal where an application is refused. The proposed new arrangements outlined should when implemented meet the difficulties identified by the Public Accounts Committee and provide better control over the operations of pathology laboratories, companies and pathologists.

The Government has given careful consideration to the implementation of arrangements for the accreditation of pathology laboratories throughout Australia. While all States, through meetings of Health Ministers, support the concept of national accreditation, to date only two States, New South Wales and Victoria, have legislation to implement such a program.

By accrediting laboratories the quality of health services should be assured and as the States have traditionally accepted responsibility for quality assurance the Commonwealth believes that accreditation of pathology laboratories is a State responsibility. However, in order to complete the package of changes I have outlined above, the Government has decided that it will operate laboratory accreditation arrangements for those States which do not have legislation currently in place. Provisional accreditation will be provided for all laboratories from the date the legislation is proclaimed. Full accreditation must be applied for through the National Association of Testing Authorities prior to seeking approved pathology practitioner/approved pathology authority status and be obtained within the following 2 year period.

Two years may appear to be too long for some laboratories to have provisional accreditation arrangements. However, the Government recognises that the National Association of Testing Authorities in conjunction with the Royal College of Pathologists will need some time to inspect and report on all laboratories throughout Australia. Moreover, some laboratories will need time to meet the guidelines as set by the National Pathology Accreditation Advisory Council.

It is not proposed to grant provisional accreditation as a matter of course. It will be necessary to apply for provisional status and to provide information relevant to the laboratories operations. It is envisaged that the order in which laboratories are assessed for acreditation purposes will have due regard to applications made for provisional accreditation.

For those States with legislation (New South Wales and Victoria) the Commonwealth will accept laboratories accredited under the legislation for the payment of Medicare benefits for services performed.

Automatic acceptance by the Commonwealth of accreditation under State legislation will depend on States adopting the National Pathology Accreditation Advisory Council's guidelines and the minimum standards. However, it is expected that these States will comply with these guidelines.
Under the proposal:
only those pathology services performed in laboratories which are accredited under State legislation or accredited by the Minister for Health will attract Medicare benefits:

while the Commonwealth will collect a fee for an application in those States where pathology accreditation does not exist, the charges associated with inspection of premises in States with legislation will be paid by the laboratory direct to the inspecting agency.
The chief effects of these accreditation proposals should be to:
remove `backyard' laboratories who currently provide poor quality services
ensure uniform minimum acceptable standards throughout Australia, and
be welcomed by the profession.
Substantially, these proposals will provide greater control and supervision over quality and standards for pathology services.

The measures provided for in the Bill and which I have outlined i.e. the reduction in certain pathology fees, the revised approved pathology practitioner arrangements and the introduction of the Approved Pathology Authority Scheme, the separation of pathology items from the existing Medicare Benefits Schedule, the removal of Item 955 from the Schedule, the restrictions on self-determined tests, accreditation of laboratories and the other measures announced, substantially implement the recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee's Report 236 on Pathology.

There are also a number of minor amendments made by the Bill including amendments to bring health legislation into line with the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. I mention, in particular, the amendment of the definition of ``dependant'' in the National Health Act to extend it to de facto spouses. Amongst other amendments, Part III of the Bill amends the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 to permit moneys held by the Commission, and not immediately required for its Medibank Private functions, to be invested by the Commission or a person or body representing the Commission; and Part V of the Bill amends the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 by raising aggregate amount limits to provide for cost supplementation arrangements determined by the Commonwealth Government and to provide for development grants as part of the transfer assistance offered to the States.
Financial Impact Statement

When implemented, the new approved pathology practitioner scheme and related measures will provide savings to the Government of approximately $60,000,000 in a full year. $47,000,000 will arise directly from reduced fees for some pathology items in the Medicare Benefits Schedule; up to $10,000,000 from the more restrictive arrangements for self-determined tests; and $2,700,000 from the removal of Item 955 from the Schedule.

Figures supplied by the Department of Social Security indicate that the amendment to the definition of ``dependant'' in the National Health Act would result in increased expenditure of approximately $700,000 in the 1986-87 financial year.
The amendments to the aggregate amount limits in the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act will result in increased expenditure of up to $2,761,000 in 1986-87.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was interrupted last night I was saying how amazing it is that with the economy going into recession, with our trade deficit this year looking as though it will be a figure of about $15 billion, with our inflation rate now twice that of our trading partners and rising when theirs is falling, with interest rates in this country still around record high levels and with the dollar struggling to stand up, we in the Senate are debating yet another new tax. This is only one of a series. Over the next fortnight we will have to debate other new taxes and imposts upon Australian business and upon the Australian economy. It is beyond the belief of the Opposition that, with the economy in such circumstances, this would be the approach of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night I was arguing that this additional tax is unwarranted and unnecessary. I argued that if the existing provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act, particularly section 26 (e), were properly enforced by the Commissioner of Taxation and with the encouragement of this Government, such a tax would be unnecessary.

I was arguing that this tax is inflationary. It is a unique tax on employers that will obviously be passed through to consumers in higher prices and higher costs of services. I was arguing that it is enormously complex in its structure and therefore fails one of the basic tenets of any tax system, that is, to aim towards a simple tax system. It will be enormously administratively expensive for business because of its complexity, at a time when we should be looking at ways of restraining the costs of administration upon our business and it is full of anomalies and technical shortcomings.

When the Senate went into its adjournment debate last night I was talking particularly about the tax as it relates to motor vehicles, that is, the fringe benefits tax upon motor vehicles provided by employers. I was referring to the enormous administrative difficulties that will face employers. They should be aware that they have to have in place within approximately five weeks their structures, their bookwork and their various registers. I am not sure that that is well appreciated. They will also have to make decisions as to which method they will adopt-whether it will be the statutory formula basis or the operating cost basis. They will have to have vehicle registers prepared and a register of odometer readings. They will have to have in place methods for determining employee private use, or so-called private use, of vehicles. They will have to have in place methods for keeping records of invoices and receipts provided by employees and so on.

In the case of the operating costs basis, the keeping of this paper work will be compulsory. In the case of the statutory formula basis it may not be compulsory but, in effect, to comply with the provisions of the legislation, in practice it will be necessary. It will be an enormous additional impost on business for it simply to get on top of the requirements, let alone to keep the records that will be necessary.

At the end of each journey-we are talking about people who regularly use their vehicles for business-they will have to keep records of the journey, the kilometres travelled, the purpose of the journey, the identity of the driver, the date of the log book entry, the names of the persons making the entry and so forth. Any reflection on this requirement will indicate just how ridiculous it is, how time consuming it will be and how administratively costly it will be.

The other point that should be made is that many people think of this tax in terms of its effect upon fringe benefits only in the form of the provision of cars. But of course that is not so. It will cover loan benefits, housing benefits, board, meals, the waiver of debts, expense payments, living away from home allowances, airline transport and property benefits. The Bill divides property benefits into in-house benefits and external benefits, with different provisions applying in each case. Then, of course, there is a residual benefits provision-an attempt to catch all that may have been otherwise missed out and to provide yet another series of rules and regulations that must be complied with in that regard. So it is not surprising that business is terrified by the administrative complexity of the work involved and also of the cost of meeting such requirements.

It is worth noting also that with the countdown only five weeks away and with the need to get books and papers in order for then, in the first nine months, which is referred to as the transitional year, in actual fact the business will have to put in three returns-two statements and one return at the end of the nine months. On even a very superficial glance that indicates the sort of obligation there will be on business immediately upon this Bill coming into law.

Time is against me because of the need to debate all the other new tax Bills introduced by this Government. This Bill has everything. First, it has tax creep. The 49 per cent rate will apply from 1 April next year rather than 1 July 1987, as is the case with other company tax provisions. Secondly, it has nonsense provisions. I remind honourable senators that in order to calculate the actual costs of car use one must take the notional interest rate imposed by the Commonwealth Savings Bank on housing loans. If anything indicates the ridiculous nature of this Bill it is the suggestion that to calculate actual rates one should use the notional determination of housing interest rates. Thirdly, this Bill has inconsistencies. For example, a discount of 40 per cent will apply to remote area housing fringe benefits, yet a discount of 50 per cent will apply to remote area holiday travel. Where is the logic of that? There are other provisions for discount rates of 75 per cent and 37 1/2 per cent. There is no logic in these provisions at all.

Arguably this legislation has areas of retrospectivity. It has been suggested that it can apply to benefits that have been granted to someone before he became an employee and this will hit a number of family situations. Also the Bill has uncertainty. The Government claims that State property will not be taxed, but what about housing provided to government employees, such as teachers and railway workers, in country areas? There is still uncertainty in that regard. Strictly under the terms of this Bill a farmhouse that is in a company name and of which the farmer is the occupant will be taxed in the hands of the company although the Government now tells us that that will not be so. Administratively the Government may believe that, but the Commissioner of Taxation is an independent statutory authority and what the Government says is certainly not what we are being asked to put into law in this chamber.

This is a petty Bill. It includes a calculation on meals in some circumstances down to the value of $1. A tax which necessitates the Commissioner putting out a booklet on how to comply even before the tax has been implemented and which includes 15 errors which must be corrected, indicates that the whole tax is very much in error--

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the Government's declarations of interest.

—Yes. This tax should be thrown out. It is my lament that the Australian Democrats will not get off the political fence on this issue and serve a worthwhile purpose to the Australian community by supporting the Opposition in this one instance and throwing out this new tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia already has a fringe benefits tax in the current Income Tax Assessment Act. Of course we on this side acknowledge that fringe benefits as such deserve to be taxed and are taxed according to the Federal Income Tax Assessment Act. However, since the Australian Labor Party came into power-more than three years ago now-it has not directed the Australian Taxation Office to enforce the current provisions fully. It is overlooking its own inadequacies in this area and taking the heat off the Taxation Office. Instead it is placing the onus on business.

SPEECH.PARA: Nowhere else in the world do we see such iniquitous provisions as those that are being presented to this Parliament today by this Government. Honourable senators might say then there is one exception-that is New Zealand, under the Lange Government. However, Prime Minister Lange condemned himself out of his own mouth when he said that 8,000 farmers in New Zealand might be forced off the land this year because of debt problems. I add that those debt problems are due to high interest rates and fringe benefits tax charges on small farmers-people who have to pay taxes on so-called benefits which their families may derive as a result of living in their own homes. This is just the forerunner of what will happen in Australia. We can see what is happening in New Zealand. This Labor Government is determined to press ahead and put Australian business and farmers deeper and deeper into crisis. It is unfortunate that the Australian Taxation Office has not acted under the present Act which could have been refined if need be. It has not attempted to overcome some of the technical difficulties in formulating the requisite criteria of tests to apply to relevant provisions. Instead, it will scrub the lot and start again in a novel way that the rest of the world with the exception of New Zealand will not have a bar of. It is dreadful.

Unfortunately we are now finding under this Labor Government that fringe benefits are no longer the preserve of the executives, as the Government tends to suggest. Fringe benefits have now grown to such proportions that they are inbred in a great number of industries. This is unfortunate. We have to acknowledge that the legislation is anti-business. It is enormously bureaucratic and will do great harm to the productive sector of the economy. These are the words of our Leader, John Howard, and how right he is. On election the coalition will repeal the Keating fringe benefits tax. It is economic insanity for the Hawke Government to introduce a wide range of anti-business taxes when this country is in a balance of payments crisis. The Government should be doing everything in its power to encourage investment and export earnings.

This country is justifiably outraged by this tax reform package particularly the fringe benefits taxation. Let us look at a few areas. We will start with motor vehicles. Sales have plunged by more than 20 per cent in the first four months this year and are expected to fall to their lowest level since 1972. Industry sources say that workers have already been retrenched in dealerships and spare parts supplies, as have transporters, detailers and those in associated industries. One source has suggested that there may be a loss of 10,000 jobs directly in the next few months. Another has suggested that the flow-on effect could rise to 25,000 jobs. The car industry alone has already been made to suffer because of high increased rates, increased prices due to devaluation of the Australian dollar and the introduction of lead-free petrol.

This fringe benefits tax is capable of being the final straw that breaks the back of many successful small businesses. I must say that my sympathies really go out to Senator Button whose views have been totally ignored by his own Party. My disgust is directed at the Australian Democrats who have opted to vote for this legislation. The wheeling and dealing of the Democrats in this fringe benefits tax debate have given them no credibility in the public eye. Their wheeling and dealing, their actions, will be the low watermark of those in that Party so far as their parliamentary careers are concerned. In no way can I support this destructive sort of legislation. We are hearing cries of anguish from the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions about the lack of business investment, but who can blame industry for not committing new capital for investment when such uncertainty is created by this tax package?

This Government appears to be under the impression that it can impose taxation measures by announcement rather than legislation, taxes which apply from the date of announcement rather than from the date of legislation. In effect, this legislation has an element of retrospectivity. But this practice creates further uncertainty. There is no certainty from the date of announcement. As soon as such measures are announced the Australian Democrats start wheeling and dealing, talking about changes, changing their minds from time to time over perhaps 12 months or more. How can business, from the date of announcement, expect to set up its plans amidst such uncertainty and with such rubbish going on? Uncertainty, misunderstanding and, indeed, fear about future security have been rife in the business community since these fringe benefits taxes were announced. In fact, so many months have now passed since these provisions were originally announced, without any legislation being sighted, that the feeling of uncertainty in the community has been exacerbated.

I believe that the fringe benefits tax legislation before the Senate is an extremely poor piece of legislation for about eight reasons, which I will go through. It departs from the basic principle of taxation because it requires the employer to pay tax on the benefits. In effect, it will be a tax on employment, like payroll tax-something we should not be imposing when an economy is in crisis. But unlike payroll tax, it will be a non-deductible tax. It will be imposed on organisations regardless of whether or not they are in a profitable position. Businesses will be committed in the first instance to pay the tax or perhaps breach a contract with their employees. As a result, they will have a limited number of options. They can take the fringe benefits tax into consideration in future salary reviews and perhaps reduce the level of increases. Of course, this will cause problems in the work place between the employee and the management. The second alternative is for businesses to pass these costs on through price increases, which ultimately will lead to inflation and damage their ability to compete in the market-place and against imports.

It has been estimated that this fringe benefits tax will also be quite inflationary. It is estimated that in the first year it will add 0.3 per cent to the inflation rate and in the second year, 0.7 per cent-thus adding to the inflation rate a figure approaching one per cent. Also, the tax could reduce the work force as employers attempt to save the cost to them. It will certainly reduce profit margins. It will be anti-business. Further, I suggest that it is middle management that will be under the greatest threat as a result of this legislation. I am sure that there will be a great endeavour by business to subcontract to even a greater extent the number of services rendered to it, rather than carrying full time staff. A partner in the firm of Mann Judd has estimated that the additional cost to business, to employers, could be as high as 32 per cent.

These options and costs will do both business and the community great damage. Unfortunately, the Government has not sufficiently analysed the costs and the problems that it will create as a result of these additional taxes. Let me emphasise that they are additional taxes on business and enterprise. They will have a quite dramatic impact on employment within this country. There is also the multiplier effect, because these taxes will flow through to a number of ancillary industries. I am sure that if the Government had done its homework it would have taken into account the increased welfare payments for thousands of families, because thousands of families will now be relegated to a life of poverty and unemployment. The answer to this problem in subsequent years will be quite frightening.

As well as being a tax on employment, it is a tax on a business input. The taxes and charges proposed are of a non-deductible nature and the fringe benefits tax fails to distinguish between job facilities and job benefits.

The fringe benefits tax is also a tax on enterprise. It will certainly increase business costs, particularly to small business. The combination of the disallowance of entertainment expenses and the fringe benefits tax, scheduled to take effect on 1 July this year, will be devastating to small and medium-size businesses such as advertising agencies and promotional organisations. We have heard nothing of those today. It will also mean additional money out of profits to be paid to the Australian Taxation Office and it will mean additional administrative costs made necessary in order to calculate the required tax and to keep up the plethora of records necessary. The administrative cost of compliance with the proposed tax will certainly be a significant proportion of the amount of money raised. So it will be costly to government and it will be even more costly to business. It will mean additional costs expended to lawyers, accountants and advisers to explain these new laws. The only winners that I can see will be the lawyers and the accountants-and certainly the Government. The documentation requirement of this tax are extremely onerous.

Unfortunately, there is no flexibility in this fringe benefits tax with regard to the financial year ending 31 March and this will mean further inconvenience for many companies. The Australian Financial Review has pointed out a further problem-that the tax will also apply to companies in receivership. This means that creditors could finish up paying the tax on behalf of the liquidated companies. Hungerford has intimated that the liquidator would almost certainly inherit unsatisfactory records and would have considerable difficulty contacting past employees to obtain the necessary fringe benefits tax declarations, adding substantially to the costs of the liquidators. Furthermore, the Commissioner of Taxation could take up to five years to issue an assessment notice of the tax, further delaying payments to creditors. This tax is very much anti-business and it cannot be tolerated. Business is suffering under this situation. The President of the New South Wales Chamber of Manufactures said that the added cost to employers could not have come at a worse time for the manufacturing industry. Companies could be forced into a position of again passing on these increased costs. This Australian Labor Party Government is the first government in the history of Australia to tax charities. Churches will be taxed with respect to their welfare and community services as opposed to their traditional clergy work. Is this Government not aware that churches and charities cannot pass on these additional costs to the aged, the disabled, the homeless and the unemployed that they serve? Is this Government not aware that the taxing of these institutions will mean a reduction in services to these disadvantaged groups, the aged, the disabled and so on? Ultimately, in spite of the proposed compensation measures, which may not even come about, the Government will have to pick up the tab for these additional welfare services which will be transferred to it.

A number of other voluntary organisations, such as the National Trust, in which my colleague Senator Newman has such an interest, for the first time will be liable to tax. In my State of Tasmania the National Trust manages something like 20 properties of national significance. Most of these properties have what is known as a live-in warden who lives on site virtually free of charge so as to keep down vandalism. These wardens are often quite elderly folk. They are dedicated people who have a vested interest in ensuring that these properties are protected and maintained for the people of this country and for future generations. They are not really employees of the Trust as such. But under this proposed legislation the National Trust will be forced to pay a fringe benefits tax on its employees' subsidised housing. The National Trust, without major fund raising activities, will be unable to meet these commitments. There will be further draws upon Government to finance these sorts of operations.

Another fact that I find abhorrent in this legislation is the fact that taxpayers who are adversely affected have no guaranteed right of appeal. If the Australian Taxation Office amends a fringe tax benefit assessment, the taxpayer can only request a reference. There is no time frame within which this review must take place. I believe that this legislation must be rejected. It is anti-business, it is anti-Australian and it is against the poor people of Australia. I believe it must be opposed at all costs.

That has been addressed in an excellent, objective and incisive article by Ross Gittins in the Sydney Morning Herald of Wednesday 28 May. I will quote from the first part of that article and then develop more arguments on it. Ross Gittins stated:

The fringe benefits tax is intended to restore the equity between the multitude of ordinary wage-earners-who've been paying tax at the full rate and have been denied even a tax deduction for their bus fares to work-and the relative handful of executives and self-employed business people who've been able to evade tax for years by getting part of their remuneration in the form of fringe benefits such as company cars, subsidised home-loans and so on.
. . . . by closing many of the main tax dodges and using the money raised to pay for hefty cuts in the rates of income tax for people earning more than $19,500-

That is what we are doing. Unfortunately, the money is not being distributed equally or equitably when it is going back. Ross Gittins in his article reminds us that there has been some furore about these pieces of legislation. He reminds us of the disruption the introduction of the bottom of the harbour legislation caused within the ranks of the Liberal Party back in 1982. Half the members of the Liberal Party wanted the legislation; the other half did not. The argument put forward then was that that legislation would close lots and lots of businesses and put thousands and thousands of people out of work. The legislation went through, and if that happened we have not heard about it.

Ross Gittins also reminded us of the decision to require builders to withhold income tax from payments to building sub-contractors from September 1983. Again, in the fear and scare campaign mounted it was said that that would inflate out of all proportion the cost of houses, putting them beyond the reach of people and spreading doom and gloom within the building industry. We need look only at the statistics in the building industry through the remainder of 1983, 1984, 1985 and even this year, 1986, to see that that did not happen. Last September another hoo-ha was mounted over the tax deductibility of business lunches, with estimates of from 10,500 to 80,000 jobs being lost as a consequence. We find that six to eight months later there is still an acute shortage of experienced chefs and waitpersons in that industry.

The Australian Financial Review is not a paper that is all the time on the side of the Australian Labor Party. I say that because it is an objective newspaper, one of the quality newspapers which one can quote with confidence as accurate. An editorial leader in that newspaper on 27 May put a case for the fringe benefits tax. Time does not allow me to quote from that editorial, but it put up three examples of the impact of the fringe benefits tax on three separate taxpayers, A, B and C, each earning $80,000 a year. Taxpayer A had a salary package in which 50 per cent of the salary was paid in fringe benefits, taxpayer B received fringe benefits of $20,000, and taxpayer C received no fringe benefits at all. Calculated on 1983-84 rates the average rates of tax on those salaries with those fringe benefit packages included would be, for taxpayer A, 20.2 per cent; for taxpayer B, 33.1 per cent; and for taxpayer C, 48.1 per cent. There is nothing fair or equitable about that.

A campaign has been mounted on this topic and taken to great heights, as would be alleged by some Opposition members. Indeed, yesterday Senator Vanstone said her office in South Australia had been flooded with calls opposing this tax. That has not been the case in Western Australia. That confirms the information and analysis in the survey made by the Australian Labor Party about this legislation. We found that fewer than one in 10 people were worried about this tax-fewer than one in 10 people thought that they would be adversely affected by any form of fringe benefits tax. That message is getting through to the community and is causing some concern to Opposition members. Perhaps this is the case for the Waste Watch Committee that from time to time floods this place with all sorts of information.

In the West Australian on Tuesday of this week we saw a full-page advertisement costing some $2,000, hopefully paid for out of Liberal Party funds, with the following bold headline: `Mr Hawke-There's nothing left to take!!'. Then the message is killed because it contains a picture of Mr Hassell, who is the Western Australian Liberal Party leader. He says:
Stop the fringe benefits tax. The proposed fringe benefits tax will hurt all Australians.
Then he says:
Act now, or it will be too late.

The action he is calling for is to get every member of the community in Western Australia to ring his or her Western Australian Labor senators in Perth or in Parliament House. This went out in a full-page newspaper advertisement on Tuesday of this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Paid for by Telecom.

—Paid for by Telecom-I am not sure. It did go out in the West Australian, the largest circulation newspaper in my home State, so many people would have seen it despite the photograph of Hassell at the top of it. The end result-and I am speaking only for myself-is that my office in Perth, on Tuesday and on Wednesday, received a grand total of 15 telephone calls, 13 of which opposed the tax and two of which favoured it. One of the opposing callers picked the wrong time to complain about the fringe benefits that parliamentarians receive. Part of the fringe benefits, as determined by that particular lady caller, was my trips to Canberra. Unfortunately, Tuesday is the worst time in the world-all honourable members could see how cranky Senator Walsh was. I accompanied Senator Walsh on the red eyeball special out of Perth at midnight Monday arriving here at 9.30 a.m. on Tuesday. If that is a fringe benefit, anyone can take it away from me now. People can tax it or do with it what they like; I do not want that type of fringe benefit. This type of legislation, the fear campaign, and the doom, gloom and despair associated with it need to be looked at again. I refer now to an editorial which appeared in the Australian Financial Review, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: However, what the entire debate has missed is the fact that New Zealand not only provided the model for our fringe benefits tax-it has successfully introduced one over a year ago.
Dire consequences have not followed. Small business has not collapsed and employers have now accepted the wisdom of levying the tax on them, rather than on employees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986, which aims to introduce a fringe benefits tax. I am concerned at the effect of such Bills on every section of the community. Senator McKiernan has just given us the Australian Labor Party socialist policy, which is to reduce everybody to the same level; that is exactly what it means, and what he has been talking about. What I think he does not realise, and perhaps the Labor Party accepts, is the fact that it is people who have made a little bit of money and who are employers in every sense of the word who provide jobs and job opportunities for people. If the Government is to keep on taxing them with fringe benefits taxes and capital gains taxes it will take away employment and we will end up with no incentive for people to provide jobs and job opportunities. The aim of this fringe benefits tax is to improve the fairness of the system for the majority of Australians-at least, this is what the Government says-by pursuing with resolve the policy of rooting out tax avoidance and evasion practices that have been found to exist on a large scale.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this Government has a fixation about tax evasion, because I feel quite sure that if one looked around one would find only quite a small number of people who are involved in tax evasion. I know that I get my tax return every year and pay; rather unwillingly like everybody else, I suppose; but I think that one has just got to realise that it is only a small percentage who are involved in tax evasion. As a result of this legislation we will see many problems arise for employers in every area with forms that have to be filled in. One has only to read the legislation provided to see just how many problems there will be. Of course, it gives employers the responsibility for declaring and deciding what are the fringe benefits taxes. If this is not done in the right way, goodness only knows what happens to them. I suppose that somebody comes up and checks them out. I am still waiting to find out what would happen then.

Employers will need additional clerical staff to help them in relation to this matter. It is bad enough for big business, and bad enough in the car business, but let us think about rural people, who at this point have an average income of only $7,600-and 35 per cent of whom are on a negative income or a zero income. How on earth will they pay fringe benefit taxes? I am blowed if I know. The legislation by which this Government proposes to apply this tax is 150 pages long, extremely complex and bureaucratic in nature, and has been drafted, I feel, without any regard for the nonsensical administrative burden that will be loaded on to business.

The matters covered in the Bill largely follow those specified in the announcement made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 19 September 1985. The legislation contains specific rules for valuing the following kinds of fringe benefits provided by employers or associates to employees on or after 1 July 1986, as follows: Provision of motor cars; interest free or low interest loans; waiver of debts; payment of private expenses; free or subsidised residential accommodation; excessive living away from home allowances; free or subsidised board; concessional fares for airline transport; entertainment for tax exempt bodies; free or discounted goods or other property; free or discounted services; and other specified benefits. I consider that the Bill will be a nightmare of administrative procedures, which are being forced upon employers. The cost of administering the tax, I believe, will be enormous. I wonder sometimes whether some employers will be prepared to keep the additional records required or will take the easy way out by paying the fringe benefits tax according to the proposed statutory formulae. In so doing, the employer will be paying more fringe benefits tax than he need to, which is, I suppose, what the Government had in mind in the first place. Likewise the employee, who would normally incur employment related expenses in carrying out a job, might also claim according to the statutory formulae-the easy way-which will result in a lower claim by that employee thereby increasing government revenue even more.

As I said earlier, taxpayers in the rural sector will be severely affected by this fringe benefits tax on residential accommodation, board and meals provided to employees. Charitable organisations, which need every dollar of income that they can get, will be required to pay fringe benefits tax on benefits supplied to employees. I believe that this is completely contrary to the previous basic exemption of charities from income tax, sales tax, bank account debit tax, and other levies and taxes. The result of this tax on charities will be counterproductive, because the charities will be forced either to reduce services or approach the Government for additional subsidies. I think there are not too many people who want to give their donations to charities realising that they are helping those charities to pay income tax.

The fringe benefits tax is expected to reduce car sales by some 35,000 this year, causing at least 10,000 car industry workers to lose their jobs and reducing the Government's passenger vehicle manufacturing plan to a farce. If one wishes to claim any part of car expenses as business expenses one must maintain a daily log book in which an entry is made for every business trip. According to information provided by my tax accountant the list is endless. I sometimes wonder whether members of the Government have really looked at what has to be supplied in claims for motor vehicle expenses. For instance, one has to provide the date on which the journey began, the date on which it ended, odometer reading at the beginning and end of the journey, number of kilometres travelled in the course of the journey, purpose of the journey, name of the person driving the car, date on which the entry was made and the name of the person making the entry-gracious me! I do not know how people are supposed to keep records like that. As I said earlier, somebody will have to be on the job especially to do that. That is why I say that I think employers, and employees, will probably take the easy way out and pay the larger amount of fringe benefits tax.

Treasury has estimated that revenue gained from company car tax will be about $350m a year. However, costs to Federal revenue resulting from a drop in sales will be some $300m; in actual fact the net revenue gain will be only $49m. Total passenger vehicle sales for the first three months of 1986 totalled 133,243 compared with 171,485 for the same period last year-a fall of 22 per cent.

Honourable senators will realise that the motor vehicle industry has already been severely hit by the devaluation of the Australian dollar, the introduction of engines which run on lead-free petrol, the increase in sales tax on motor vehicles and the adverse effects of the Government's high interest rates policy. I believe that to add to the industry's difficulties, with this new tax, at severe cost to government revenue, is quite unacceptable. Mr Keating has admitted that it would be better to cut the Commonwealth deficit further than to cut private sector activity, because it is private sector activity which will put in place the investment which will give us a better level of local production to compete with imports. Why is he imposing all of these taxes on so-called fringe benefits-taxes which are, in reality, taxes on incentives?

Independent analysis shows that this tax package could mean that employers will pay as much as an extra 32 per cent per employee, at a time when we have massive unemployment, rampant inflation and a huge balance of payments deficit. I sometimes wonder whether the Government sees it as a way to increase employment, because employers must substantiate their claims and expenditure. I wonder whether that means that one must send all of one's receipts to the Australian Taxation Office. If so, honourable senators could imagine the tremendous number of people who would be necessary in the Taxation Office to process those receipts. Of course, more inspectors would be needed to police this measure.

I turn to another aspect of the tax which I find extremely worrying-that is, the effects it will have on charities. I realise that certain exemptions will apply to ministers of religion engaged in religious duties. However, what about ministers of religion who are working for charitable and educational institutions?

TALK.START.PARA: —We will move an amendment on that, Senator.

—That will be very good. I hope that the Government will accept it because it is very important. I feel that these people are just as involved in a religious occupation as is the normal parish minister. I refer, for example, to a chaplain at a hospital or a supervisor at a youth rehabilitation centre. Committed lay persons employed by the churches, although not ordained ministers, exercise the duties of a religious ministry just as effectively as if they were ordained clergy. At the same time they are paid minimum salaries in comparison with those receiving secular wages.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to a letter that was written to me by the Superintendent of the Parramatta Regional Mission of the Uniting Church in Australia in which he stated that the church has a Life Line Co-ordinator for the whole western area who is a lay person and who performs several roles which, if undertaken by the Government, would cost three times as much. The mission also employs a lay person who cares for battered and bashed women on a full time basis. If this service were run by the Government, it says, it would cost four times as much. The Superintendent told me that the mission employs a lay person who works for at least 100 hours per week, handling crisis situations which involve counsel- ling, religious understanding and support, and the provision of basic needs. If the Government were to undertake this task, the cost would be four times higher. The Superintendent stated:

. . . we believe that the imposition of this tax on such an employing body will result in a lessening of the ability of the Church to assist people of Australia doomed to the added cost burden resulting in our ability to employ needed staff.

Also, there is the fact that the cars operated by charities that are taken home by employees will attract as much as $40,000 in tax. This will mean cost cutting in the areas of supervision, education, camps and excursions, and programs which ease the burden of disabled people. Recently I attended a function organised by the Blue Nursing Service in Brisbane. The administration told me that if the cars that the Blue Nurses take home in the evenings in order to start their rounds the next morning are taxed, they will have a tremendous job to raise enough money to meet the cost of the Blue Nursing Service which, of course, is very important to sick people confined to their homes. I think the Government must look very carefully at this area. The Returned Services League has stated:

What started out as an attack by the Government on company executives has ended up as an attack on cha- ritable and welfare organisations. These tax exempt non-government bodies, most of which are struggling to make ends meet and to maintain their current level of services, will now be hit by a tax where none existed before.

Industry and business will spend vast amounts of money in gathering the tax for the Government. This cost will have to be added to prices and that, of course, will create further inflation and diminish our competitiveness in overseas export markets, which we desperately need to develop. For example, Australia's mining industry, which generates so much of our overseas income, will be hit for millions of dollars per year in tax in regard to the provision of subsidised housing for employers in remote areas. Sir Bruce Watson of MIM Holdings Ltd has stated that it would cost more than $30m a year, which represents 5 per cent of the net profit of the entire mining industry last year. That is a lot of money in anybody's language.

The tax on concessional air travel by airline employees will cost employers substantial amounts. It would be naive to think that it will not end up adding to the price of a ticket. The fringe benefits tax will take millions of dollars from State government coffers-no doubt to be replaced by increased State taxes and charges. The Queensland Government says that under section 114 of the Constitution-which I read in the House yesterday-the Federal Government is not able to tax State governments. I received a letter also from a local government council in Queensland which was very concerned about the effect of the proposed fringe benefits tax on its shire, which is only small. It said that the proposed fringe benefits tax would cost approximately one per cent of the shire's rate revenue.

These are all problems that are being raised. Public utilities will also be caught in the fringe benefits tax net and hikes will occur in the price of electricity, gas, water, postage, telephones and associated services. Of course, there is no doubt that the effects on farmers and the rural sector generally will most certainly be disastrous. I will not dwell too long on that point because I have mentioned it previously. If an employer provides a residence to a farm worker and the worker's family, the employer will be taxed on the value of that residence. The employer will be taxed on the value of farm produce provided to a farm worker and his family, and also on the value of electricity, gas or fuel supplied to the farm worker's residence. One could go on and on. I doubt very much whether the Government has given enough consideration to all of the problems that will be caused to so many sections of our community. The other day I read in an issue of Dateline News Digest that the Treasurer had sought to reassure the Parliament that the fringe benefits tax would not prove to be unduly harsh on farmers. In light of what I have said, I do not see how he can say that it will not be unduly harsh on them. I think it will be very harsh indeed. It will be a real problem, as I see it. Even residential accommodation provided to employees in remote areas will be subject to the fringe benefits tax. I think the best thing the Government could do would be to abandon this tax altogether.

The National Party of Australia believes that this tax will be a major impediment to increased productivity and competitiveness-the very thing that Australia desperately needs to improve its economy and create lasting job opportunities. We certainly remain opposed to this tax, as is also the case in regard to the capital gains tax, the assets test and the 3 per cent superannuation deal with the trade unions. As far as I can see, Labor is trying to drive all incentive and initiative out of Australia's most efficient and industrious innovators-our small business and productive export industries. I certainly find it worrying that the Australian Democrats have only seen fit to try to negotiate with the Government on the effect of this tax on our motor vehicle industry. I believe that they should be doing what the Australian public wants them to do, that is, to oppose the tax outright. I am sure that they have had lots of requests to do that. I feel that the Government is trying to impose on every section of the community a tax that is most unwarranted.

The real reason why the Government is trying to find reasons to cut down on its tax cuts is most likely to be the threatening blow-out in the 1985-86 Budget deficit and its inability to hold the economic trilogy promises made in the 1984 election campaign. We all realise that this Government has the greatest deficit of all time-$80 billion-with an interest bill on that of $15 billion a year. In fact 40 per cent of this nation's exports go to paying the interest bill alone.

The Business Council of Australia has warned that next year's Budget could blow out to over $6 billion unless the Government changes its economic policy. An independently prepared report by Westpac Banking Corporation and the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research shows that economic activity in Australia fell by 2.3 per cent in February 1986. I believe that a fringe benefits tax will be the last straw that will break the camel's back in very many cases. I include all employers in Australia-big business, small business, rural employers and charities. A fringe benefits tax is certainly not the way to solve our deep economic problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax Bill 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Bill 1986 and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986, which are timed to come into force on 1 July. This debate has been canvassed long and strong in the Australian community, starting when this Government grasped the nettle for tax reform-something that had not been addressed under the previous Government-and confronted many of the inequities and anomalies that have been allowed to gather and grow strong and are now believed by several proponents of them to be rights. Nonetheless, they are still anomalies in our tax system.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the greatest scandals that the Fraser Government bequeathed to Australia is that, during all the time that it occupied the treasury bench, it never generated any enthusiasm in its own ranks for real reform of taxation. It presided over a haemorrhaging of the revenue base of the Government, it blinked at tax avoidance and it acknowledged tax evasion but did little to counter it. The history of the tax story for the Fraser Government provides a very important clue as to why the Australian Labor Party is on the treasury bench.

One of the things the people of Australia have come to know about the Fraser Government is that it was a government that tolerated tax avoidance, tolerated inequity, tolerated unfairness, shifted the burden of revenue on to the backs of wage and salary earners and allowed those at the luxury end of the market to escape their tax obligations to the nation while claiming all of the benefits on the expenditure side of the Budget they could put their greasy hands on. That whole expose was well understood and is one of the reasons why the Labor Party is in government. In addressing its mandate as a government it is one of the things we have tackled fully, comprehensively, with great consultation and with a sense of fairness and justice in an effort to redesign a comprehensive taxing regime in Australia that is simple, that is equitable, that is fair, that closes off avoidance and evasion and that is efficient. We have done that by conducting, over the course of last year, a major debate in this country on what the principles of tax reform should be, by culminating that debate in the National Taxation Summit in which all the key players in this field put their cases and by synthesising the argument in that Summit in the form of the legislation that is coming forward now and of which these Bills are a part. No other government in the history of this nation has had the courage to do that. No other government in the history of this nation has had the courage to confront the sacred cows of the taxation system and, where they are wrong and inequitable, identify them, overturn them and bring equity to reign. Whatever else is said in this debate, that point has to be well and truly and fundamentally understood.

In many respects for those of us who have been part of this debate over the last 18 months the passage of these Bills to this stage in the Senate is an anticlimax. If the final carriage of this legislation is to be more like a whimper than a bang, I think the whimper we heard from Senator Bjelke-Petersen in her remarks a moment ago epitomise the limp and pathetic arguments of the Opposition. She said-this was the theme of many of the speakers on the other side of the chamber in this debate-that, should these Bills pass, the economy will come to a shuddering halt, all Armageddon will break loose and, as with Chicken Little, the sky will fall in. Let me refer to an independent commentator, the editor of the Australian Financial Review, who on Tuesday, 27 May, in an editorial headlined `The case for the fringe benefit tax', stated:
However, what the entire public debate has missed is the fact that New Zealand not only provided the model for our fringe benefit tax-it has successfully introduced one, over a year ago.
Dire consequences have not followed. Small business has not collapsed and employers have now accepted the wisdom of levying a tax on them, rather than on employees.
Surely, if such a tax works successfully for the kiwis, there is nothing to stop it working even more successfully here.
The Australian Financial Review editors conclude:
They may be able to beat the pants off us at Rugby and cricket but surely we can at least try for a draw on tax reform.

If I can just put real life experience against the hysterical utterings of the Opposition and doom-laden forecasting, as the editors of the Australian Financial Review point out-and that is not a Labor party organ, as everyone who reads it knows-by identifying the New Zealand experience of this tax, what the Opposition is forecasting is just arrant rubbish. People talk about confidence in this economy. At a time when we have a balance of payments problem, which is being addressed by the Government, I suggest that the most positive thing which the Opposition can do is to reach a bipartisan accommodation with this Government, to talk with some confidence about the economy and to get off its carping criticism and start to play a positive role. Let me go back to this debate on tax. As I have said, the most important public event for us was the National Taxation Summit last year from which we synthesised the contributions, debated them and brought forward these Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you reckon that was a success?

—By exposing the objectives of the Government we run the gauntlet of argument such as we have just heard in that interjection: Do we think that that was a success? This Government has never apologised that it is a government that seeks to find consensus in the community. We do not have the Opposition's complex about being born to rule and knowing what is right ultimately to the last point. We believe in consulting the main players in the community, in taking their views on board, in listening to what they have to say and, on the basis of that community consultation and our mandate, in enacting legislation which reflects the widest possible consensus. I suspect that if the honourable senator ever wants to return to this side of the Senate he should learn from that and listen to the voices in the community. We did it and that is why this legislation is before us.

SPEECH.PARA: Having exposed our intention on the legislation we did not at that point close off the consultative process. Everyone who is listening to this debate would know that every single interest lobby group has been sprinting up the front steps of Parliament House with their hot little submission about why their particular taxation rort should be protected. We have shown great forbearance in listening to those arguments and, if there is merit in them, in addressing the merit that is being put forward in order to ensure that, while the principle of the tax is protected, its introduction occurs in a way which will cause the least possible economic damage. While I assert strongly, and while it is certainly by any objective argument the case, that the consultation process in which we have engaged represents the broad mass of the community, we have also been sensitive to particular detailed points which those lobbies have brought forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the charities.

—If the honourable senator wishes, I will come to some of his arguments in a minute. I promise him that I will not miss him. He may regret that mindless interjection. The problem we had in addressing the tax scales was, as I have said, that one cannot take this argument piecemeal. Comprehensive surgery is necessary to bring equity and fairness back into the taxation laws of this nation. That is necessary because the Fraser Government bequeathed to us a revenue base that was haemorrhaging, a situation in which wage and salary earners-those who could not escape tax obligations because the tax is deducted from their wages-paid the overwhelming share of taxes and those who had income which enabled them to avoid taxes avoided their obligations. In the end the net effect was that the wealthy could avoid the tax and the wage and salary earners paid it. That might be a Liberal Party of Australia concept of justice but it certainly is not for the rest of the community, and it certainly is not for this Government. One of the major areas of avoidance is the provision of fringe benefits in lieu of income. Under the existing tax legislation I have long held that fringe benefits are taxable and ought to have been taxed.
—Why didn't you use the existing taxation laws?
—Why did not the previous Government?
—Why didn't you use it? You have been in power for three years.

—We are about to. If the honourable senator stays in the chamber long enough he will see the vote and see us do it, which is more than can be said for the previous Government's record. We have tackled the rort of a benefit being received not in cash but in kind by taxing that kind of benefit on its value to the receiver of it, but taxing the supplier of it and not the receiver. We have had the rort by which senior company executives are given company cars in lieu of wages, by which the school fees of their children at private schools are paid in lieu of wages, by which all their special expenses-their superannuation benefits and all those other sorts of peculiar pension plans-are paid. Those benefits are given to avoid the payment of wages and salaries but are nonetheless of benefit to an employee, albeit a senior executive, and they will under these Bills now be taxed. That is quite proper. Without it, we would be tolerating an inequity that is certainly not in our mandate; we will not tolerate that.

SPEECH.PARA: The impact of these proposals is to be revenue neutral. We have not set out to expand the revenue base of the Government. We have set out to rearrange it so that it is equitably spread. One of the greatest furphies that the Opposition has concentrated on putting abroad is that the real debate about taxation ought to be about the amount of government expenditure. That is just so much rubbish. Whatever the level of government expenditure, whether it be our level or what the Opposition believes should be the level, income has to be raised to finance it.
