That is what this legislation is about. We say that the income levels that are necessary for government expenditure will be raised fairly. The Opposition says: `Reduce the income but leave the unfairness in the system to make sure that those who cannot avoid tax do not and that those who can and who have the wealth to do so can do so'.

One of the other major furphies in this debate is that there is no support for the Government in its pursuit of this line of approach. Well, I am advised that a number of research studies have been undertaken. If we take together all of those reports, the main indications coming from them-there are five of them-are that the fringe benefits tax continues to have strong majority support. As many as three in four people think that some form of fringe benefits tax should be introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did they learn about it?

—Not from Senator Townley. The fringe benefits tax is seen as the best feature of the tax package. In fact it is even more popular than the consequent tax cuts that will flow from it this year and next year. Thirdly, fewer than one in 10 people wanted the fringe benefits tax on cars dropped. That says nothing about the details, such as the rates of tax, et cetera, on cars. Fourthly, approximately one person in 10 thought he would be adversely affected by the fringe benefits tax. That runs directly contrary to the main theme of argument that the Opposition is putting up. Fifthly, the majority response to the tax package was that it would make the tax system fairer, particularly because it would close off abuses of the system, that it would help reduce tax avoidance and would lead to reductions in the income tax rates.

SPEECH.PARA: On that last point let me just say that the Opposition has taken the soft cop line of argument by generally indicating its support for the tax cuts but by attacking the revenue raising mechanisms necessary to finance them. As I have constantly said in this debate, we are making the system fairer by reducing the burden on pay as you earn taxpayers. The Opposition supports the reduction in income tax but opposes the method of raising the income in order to finance it. That is the glorious irresponsibility of opposition and it is one of the reasons why those opposite will remain in opposition.

This debate has risen on the hysteria index the closer we get to the enactment of the legislation. A number of the arguments put by Opposition senators during this debate are best answered not from me but again by another independent economic commentator, this time the economics editor of the Sydney Morning Herald, Ross Gittins. In an article on 28 May under the heading `It's time for a few home truths about the perks tax', he states:

I can remember back to the tumultuous days of late 1982, for example, when half the Liberal Party tried to dissuade the other half from using retrospective legislation to collect some of the tax lost in the bottom-of-the-harbour companies.

One of the many arguments used at the time was that the tax dodge by people who sold their companies to bottom-of-the-harbour merchants had been ploughed back into their businesses. If the Government went back many years later and demanded the tax, lots of small businesses would have to fold up and lay off all their workers.
That had been the proposition put forward in the arguments by Opposition senators. He continued:
Well, the recoupment legislation went through and the back taxes were collected, but if lots of firms went bust in the process we never got to hear about it.

I can remember all the hoo-ha over the decision to require builders to withhold tax from payments to their sub-contractors from September, 1983. Remember? It was going to cause the price of homes to skyrocket and cause massive unemployment in the building industry? The tax went ahead, but the sky didn't fall in after all.

And last September, remember how the removal of tax deductibility for business lunches was going to cause more than 7,000 restaurants to close within the next six months and more than 10,500-or was it 80,000-jobs would be lost?
He continues-I will conclude with this paragraph:

No doubt some restaurants have closed and no doubt some workers have been laid off. But the long-standing shortage of chefs and experienced waitpersons remains, and employment in the hospitality industry continues to rise.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the housing industry? It isn't going very well.

—I just want to dwell for a moment on restaurants. According to job vacancies notified to the Commonwealth Employment Service, there is an absolute shortage of labour in the hospitality sector. If the fringe benefits tax on restaurants has had the damaging effect on employment that the Opposition so alarmingly alleged it would have, there would be a surfeit of skilled labour cramming the CES offices around this country in search of jobs. The reverse is true.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bjelke-Petersen talked about this tax being a loss of incentive. She was saying that those who have money to invest are the only ones concerned about incentive. What about the incentive for an ordinary taxpayer who pays his full amount of tax but has to watch blatant avoidance go on? Senator Bjelke-Petersen talked about the huge cost of this tax to the mining industry. She said that the total cost of the tax was $30m. It may well be that she is quite accurate about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't care, would you?
—I do care because I have a special interest in the mining industry. I certainly care.
—The industry is broke.

—The mining industry is not broke. It is facing a glut of supply from around the world with low commodity prices and therefore it is addressing that problem by volume sales. However, Senator Bjelke-Petersen says that the cost is $30m. She is just looking at one cost. Let us take a comprehensive view of the costs and benefits of this tax to the mining sector. If one refuses to take a more global and comprehensive view and looks at just one corner of the picture, picking out what one wants to see and ignoring the rest, one can make the case that Senator Bjelke-Petersen has made. One can talk about a one dimensional view of the costs. But because this Government reduced the price of oil-and let us single out from the whole mining industry the iron ore sector of the Pilbara-the windfall gain for this reduction was $30m for that sector alone. If one looks at the effect of the devaluation on the iron ore industry in the Pilbara, one sees a windfall gain of $458m. For that industry the cost of this tax will be $16m. I ask the Senate to contemplate the position: What is fair when there are windfall gains of $30m as a result of oil price reductions and $458m as a result of devaluation and a cost incurred of only $16m?
—What about higher import costs?

—Well, there may never be a time when it is appropriate to introduce tax reform but if one is operating in a climate in which those sorts of savings occur, it seems that that is an appropriate time for one to make that reform.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the motor vehicle industry. All the dire predictions about job losses in this industry are based on the belief that companies will not buy cars to provide their employees with a benefit in kind instead of income because employers now must pay the cost of tax on those cars. The Opposition ignores the fact that the Government has reduced that tax quite considerably and it concentrates on the need to keep a log book and other minor matters. These are minor matters. What the Opposition never says and what all the commentators acknowledge is that last year many of the sales that were made on motor vehicles were brought forward from this year and there was record trading in motor vehicles. It is not surprising therefore that this year the pickings have been a bit leaner. It is not surprising either, because of the hysterical lobby that has been mounted and because of the special case of the Australian Democrats making representations to the Government, that many people are waiting for these Bills to pass before they buy cars this year. While Opposition members attack us for driving motor car sales down with this tax, they are gloriously oblivious to or ignore the fact that under the Fraser Government the unleaded petrol conditions were imposed and that has been a cost as well.

In summary, these Bills should, and appropriately will, be passed by the Senate. These Bills bring symmetry, fairness and equity, simplicity and efficiency to our taxing system. These Bills are part of a comprehensive review of our taxation system which will provide tax cuts this year and next year to wage and salary earners. These Bills will compensate for those tax cuts by closing off tax shelters and tax avoidance methods used in other parts of the income tax base. For those reasons, these Bills will provide the Government with the ability to meet the obligation imposed by its mandate for tax reform and the basis for an efficient and better taxation system in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax Bill 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Bill 1986 and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986. This tax is in my view-and that of many others-the most mean-minded, the most falsely projected, misrepresented and ill-conceived tax that has ever come before this Parliament.
—You just wish that you had had the guts to do it yourselves.

—When I hear Senator Gareth Evans interjecting and when I listen to speeches like the one from Senator Cook I am reminded of Shakespeare, who said that the devil can cite scripture for his purpose. The purpose of a socialist government is to get more and more tax money for its wasteful and gross overexpenditure and to pretend that it is taking that money out of the hides of a small number of affluent people. In the course of this speech I will demonstrate that that is false doctrine and false scripture. Indeed, this tax legislation will harm virtually every person in Australia. This legislation is not aimed at a few; it will be passed on in costs and everyone will suffer. The important thing to keep in mind is that this Bill comes at a time when there is a smell of decay and panic in the ranks of the Australian Labor Party and, indeed, among the Australian Democrats. This is strongly reminiscent of 1975. There are fallouts among Ministers who are quarrelling. We have an impotent Prime Minister who is incapable of asserting any authority, not knowing what is right but very responsive to the Left, and a blustering and bullying Treasurer who, having been built up falsely, is now shown to have feet of clay.

SPEECH.PARA: This tax, which will do great damage to the economy, must be put in perspective. It can only pass this Senate and this Parliament because seven Australian Democrat senators not only are allowing it to pass, but also are the urgers and the implementers of the legislation. Everyone in Australia who ultimately suffers from this tax must keep in mind that, although members of the Australian Labor Party are the architects of this tax, the Australian Democrats are the implementers. They have put out particularly false and ugly propaganda in order to justify their actions. I will proceed to examine that.

Australia is in recession. The Australian Labor Party is the last to be able to argue against that statement because in opposition the Labor Party repeatedly said that the test of recession was two quarters of negative growth. In opposition, the whole of the Labor Party gave us that test. Yet that is exactly what was revealed yesterday. We could also take another test that has been used by the Labor Party in the past. I take joy in reminding myself of the past. A report of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development came out which had some minor comfort in it, but the Labor Party said at the time: `You must not take any notice of that; those OECD reports are written by the governments of the day'. We remember that. We now have the test of recession and the test of what is before us.

What do we have? We have had two quarters of negative growth and a devastating slap in the face for the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), and the Government itself in the decline in investment in manufacturing industry. On two occasions now the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions has said that there is no industry policy. Indeed, there has been no response to that. It is no substitute for policy that the Minister smiles his cherubic grin and says that he is really not responsible because he does not hold with many of the policies of his Government. I remind the Senate that historically washing one's hands is no absolution of guilt. Indeed, what is necessary is to face up to policy itself.

We have also had the extreme lesson of the adverse balance of trade. That, taken with these other three matters, is a symptom that we are being costed out of world markets because of our unduly high costs of production. Everything that increases costs of production-and everybody who is interested in the Democrats' actions should understand this-harms Australia. By implementing this legislation the Democrats are harming Australia grossly. This legislation will cause unemployment and very serious hardship.

This is a strange tax. The utterly false rhetoric about it by the Australian Labor Party and the Democrats must be understood. They say: `Look, it is a good tax because a handful of rich people are tax dodgers. They get away with it. We will take the money from them and give it back to you'. That is the background, but it is not true. Those tax dodgers will not be touched at all. They will not be asked to pay the tax. They will go on cheerfully tax dodging. Let that be perfectly understood by every Australian. Those tax dodgers are to be protected, because the employer who gives them the benefit by negotiation is to pay the tax. What an extraordinary situation. What humbug. Let nobody believe that the argument put forward by the Labor Party and the Democrats on the fringe benefits tax has any legs to run on. The argument is grossly false. The employer has four opportunities to pay the tax. Incidentally, it is an ugly tax for another reason: It is not tax deductible as a cost. It increases production costs at a time when every such cost, wilfully imposed by governments or the Democrats, damages people. There is no doubt about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an addition to costs.

—Yes, and the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats, at a time of 8 per cent unemployment-prospectively growing unemployment-and a threat to the living standards of Australians, are wilfully engaging in a behind the doors compact to increase costs of production. What can an employer do? With those who have the clout, the affluent, he can renegotiate so that they do not suffer. So we will not catch such people. The affluent either go on as they are today and the employer pays or the employer renegotiates and the affluent get the same benefit. That must be absolutely understood by everybody.

SPEECH.PARA: We go one step further. Of course, the employer can withdraw the benefit. He will do so in many small businesses that cannot afford to pay. What kind of benefits are we talking about? Are we talking about cars or paying children's school fees? Not a bit; we are talking about the assistant in the butcher's shop who gets cheap or free meat. That will be taxed. The employer of the person in a warehouse or shop who gets goods at a discount will be subject to tax. The farmer whose farm is managed by his son and whose son lives at home will have to pay tax on the board and lodging of his son. We can go on. The Salvation Army and other non-clerical people who are the do-gooders of this world, and the hundreds of thousands of small people-the wage earners who Senator Cook pretended would not be touched-will all be touched. We can withdraw cheaper meat for butchers' assistants, discounts for the ordinary employee on low wages in a warehouse and benefits for poor people working for the Salvation Army or elsewhere. Thousands of such incidents have been revealed in this debate. This will not affect the affluent tax dodgers. The people mentioned are not the tax dodgers. All this Government will have done is hurt those who cannot protect themselves.

What an employer can do, and what a number of employers have indicated they will do if they are to face the problems of increased costs, is sack their staff. We have all heard of a farmer who has three employees who live in cottages on the farm at no rent or minimal rent and get what is called the run of the knife-some free meat and vegetables and a bit of milk from the jersey cow. He will be required to pay tax for providing the nominal rent on the houses and the free food for the employees. Those poor benighted employees get a very low wage anyhow, about $250. What will the employer do? He will sack one of the three employees. That is the kind of nonsense we are dealing with.

If such actions are not resorted to one thing is absolutely certain-every employer facing higher costs will pass them on, right through the costs of production to the product, whether goods or services. Is it the wealthy, the affluent, the fellows who get the motor cars or have their kids' school fees paid who will suffer? Not at all. If the costs are passed on every member of the community-pensioners, fixed income earners, poor people and low income earners alike-will have to pay them.

TALK.START.PARA: —A little old lady who puts her tithe into the collection box at the church to pay for the rent on the manse.

—That is right. The legislation is riddled with the most injurious kinds of actions by this Government. I want to dwell forcibly on the fact that this legislation will not rectify the tax injustice of a few wealthy people getting a few lurks because the tax law as it has existed has always enabled this Government and the Commissioner of Taxation to do exactly that. This legislation will protect those wealthy people. They will not have to pay the tax. They will still get all those benefits of cars and so on, because they are the few who have the clout. They cannot be sacked because they are in key positions. They have all the clout in the world, so the employer will pay the tax. The affluent will be entrenched as tax dodgers. If ever a government set out to entrench tax dodging this Government has done so. As I said before, these people can renegotiate. If benefits are withdrawn to save costs, hundreds of thousands of little people on low incomes inevitably will suffer. If in the long run all this tax is passed on in costs, we will have an absolute disaster.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at this matter, because the Democrats' role fascinates me. There is some kind of pay off. First, the Democrats are making a big thing out of the fact that they will rectify something to do with motor cars, not something concerning the Salvation Army, the butcher's assistant or the thousands and thousands of little people. They can go to blazes as far as the Democrats are concerned. The Democrats have picked one instance as a symbol-as a pretence -of what they are doing. The motor car industry says that what the Democrats are doing will not bring relief anyway. The arrangement is most peculiar. As I understand it, the Democrats will agree to the legislation if income taxes are reduced in December. Let us consider that. If the taxes are not reduced in September and the Democrats support that, by negotiating that deal they are punishing every taxpayer. They are saying by negotiating that deal: `We will make a better deal with the Government and we will keep those people on unduly high tax for another three months'. Indeed, many of them will go into a higher tax bracket in that time. What benefit is that? It is a gross detriment.

If the Democrats wanted to take the weight off the Government in terms of bargaining for higher wages for higher productivity, they should have done something about it. But fundamentally, the Australian Democrats are doing two things: By letting the fringe benefits tax go through they are saying to the people of Australia: `We do not care a hoot about you, except for a few motor car people, and all you little people can bear the burden. We do not care if this is passed on to everybody, including pensioners'. What is more, it as a result of their little trade the tax cuts do not come through on 1 September but in December, they will have put a burden of tax on everybody.

Senator Cook and others have put forward another little bit of false scripture for their purpose. They have said: `Here is an Opposition trying to stop the collection of tax which would enable us to cut taxes'. That is the greatest humbug and nonsense on earth. The fact of the matter is that whenever the people of Australia get this $7 or $8 a week tax cut, at the very best, it will simply be catching up with inflation-and even then not totally. It is no gain at all. It is a belated recognition of the tax creep caused by inflation. In fact, it is a retrospective detriment in itself. The longer the tax cuts are delayed, the longer the people are punished. Let no one say that the Government needs this money to pay tax cuts. If we do our sums we realise that the volume of inflation taxation this Government has reaped in recent years has been necessary to a great extent simply to pay for the tax cuts. Let us not have that type of humbug at all. Basically, we have before us a mean-minded tax which picks on little people. It is mean-minded and falsely projected because the Government pretends that it will hurt the big fellow who gets the benefits when in fact the big fellow's protection will continue to be entrenched, and the employer will pay. It is mean-minded because it attacks the butcher's assistant, the clerk in the warehouse, the worker for the Salvation Army and hundreds of thousands of other people. It is a pretence because the Government says it will take from the rich and give to the poor; it is a pretence because the country's economy at this moment is going downhill.

Let us remember what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said in recent days and what subsequent events have indelibly underlined. He has said that if we do not take certain actions we will be a banana republic and a Third World country. It is enormously significant that it is a Labor Treasurer, not the Opposition, who has said that we are on the way to becoming a banana republic and a Third World country. If he wants proof of this, of course, an enormous trade deficit has come forward. What does the Government say? It says: `You cannot blame us for the trade deficit because the prices of our primary industry and mining exports have fallen'. The Government forgets to say that offsetting that is the huge increase in the volume of wheat, minerals and coal that we put on the market.

The Government does not look at the other side of the ledger. Why do we have a trade deficit? It is because we cannot stop the flood of imports coming into Australia. The two effects of that are that because Australia's costs of production are so outrageously high we have 8 per cent of our population out of work and an advisory body to the Government says that we will have 8 or 9 per cent out of work for the next 10 years. The Government has not denied that. More than 20 per cent of the young in the 15 to 19 and 19 to 25 age groups are permanently out of work. The average period for a person out of work in Australia has risen from roughly 33 weeks a few years ago-which is outrageous anyhow-to over a year. The young face unemployment indefinitely. This is simply because our manufacturing industry has no policies at all. It is simply because we are being costed out of production. We are very keen to observe the advice of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. After all, the only consensus in Australia is in fact an agreement behind the Chair between the Government and the trade unions, and we have a confrontation of those two groups against the rest of the community. A government interested in doing that surely ought to take notice of two things which the ACTU has said in recent days: First, that there is no industry policy-nor there is-and, secondly, that one of the keys to this problem is to have an industry policy that works so that we can get the costs of production down and productivity up. I have not heard this Government talk about costs of production. It runs away from that issue. It talks about the side issues and symptoms. It does not get to the real nub of the problem. If we allow this situation to go on, if we continue to do a damnable thing and index inflation to deliberately maintain or increase our margin of detriment compared with the countries with which we are trading, we will cause a much greater fall in living standards and much greater unemployment. But nobody talks about that at all, only about all sorts of side symptoms.

There are two ways of solving this problem. We could do what this Government has done for nearly four years. We could pull the second greatest confidence trick-the fringe benefits tax must be the greatest-that has ever been inflicted on a people by saying that over three years and three months everything is going well and that everything is fine, that we are doing the right thing and rectifying the economy. However of course, this Government disguised the fact that all it has done for three years and three months, having benefited from the wage freeze of the Fraser Government, the coming of rain and a better economic climate including a better American economy, has been negative things. In fact, the Government has institutionalised Australia's detriment as against the rest of the world. It said it would index inflation in Australia, but inflation today is at 9.2 per cent. Not only is this twice the level of that of our trading partners, but the inflation rate for Japan and West Germany and others is virtually zero. Everything we do has the same effect. We put up excise on petrol and thereby put up the consumer price index. The Labor Government has institutionalised the detriment that is now revealed. Let nobody say that we are not in recession, because by the Government's own measure we are.

Now along comes something else. At a time when every indication is not to touch costs of production and not to disturb the relationship between employer and employees because we want maximum co-operation, the Government comes along and says it will put a significantly increased cost on every employer, small business and farmer alike, and also on the charitable institutions-in effect, that it will increase costs. The Government pretends that it is attacking the wealthy when in fact it knows that those extra costs will be passed on to the smallest among us, the most humble, the most unprotected, such as pensioners and the like. I know nothing that is more damnably ugly-if honourable senators will pardon the vigour of my speech-and I know nothing that has been more falsely represented in this country than the dogma of the Government. It has been an outrage, and this tax lends itself to it. It is no good Ministers getting up saying: `She'll be right; the J-curve will turn around'. The J-curve has dropped. It is now an economic jay walk of massive proportions.

I want to conclude by saying what I said at the beginning of my speech. This legislation is mean-minded because it hurts little people. It is falsely projected because it pretends to do what it does in reverse; it pretends to pick on the big and the affluent and in fact it hurts the little and the unprotected. It is grossly ill-conceived because it comes at a time when Australia needs reductions in costs of production. I repeat what I said at the start. This can happen to Australia only because of seven people. If tax cuts are deferred until December, which is likely, this will be supported by some kind of compact by those seven people. The Australian Democrats have it within their power to stop this legislation. At the outset, one or more of the Australian Democrats who knew how bad the legislation was said that it was bad and they opposed it in total. What has happened has been a falling back for some kind of behind the scenes arrangement. But whatever may happen, this legislation will pass. It is wrong that it should pass. It will do great harm to Australians.

The Australian Labor Party is the architect of this legislation; but no one can blame a socialist architect. After all, the failure of socialist architecture has been written in the history books of this world for hundreds of years. It goes on and on in this world in its benign nonsense. But we can blame those who know better and who do worse. I looked up a little quotation by an American named Lyman Beecher 150 years ago. He made a prayer which I make today. He said:
O Lord grant that we may not despise our rulers. And grant, O Lord, that they may not act so we can't help it.
This Government is acting in a way that will place a great strain on us not to despise it because of the falsity of the projection and the adverse impact of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 and related Bills. After an absolutely disgraceful delay we now have before us legislation which will impose a tax which was first announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 19 September 1985-some eight months ago. The Treasurer has had eight months to prepare this legislation which is now before the Senate. This legislation will impose a tax which is to apply from 1 July 1986-but seven weeks away. The Treasurer apparently believes that it is reasonable for him to take eight months to prepare this legislation but he then takes the view that taxpayers need only seven weeks to see the legislation before they begin to incur the liability, to be able to understand this complex legislation and to be in a position to pay the fringe benefits tax. As if the contempt which the Treasurer has shown for employers who will have to pay this tax is not bad enough in itself, it pales into utter insignificance when compared with the contempt which the Government has been prepared to show to employers in the way that the Government has chosen to tackle the issue of the taxing of fringe benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, this Bill will operate by requiring employers to determine the actual value of the fringe benefits which they give to their employees. Once the value is determined the employer becomes liable to pay fringe benefits tax on that value. The tax which the employer is required to pay will initially be 46 per cent of the value of the benefit but ultimately that will rise to 49 per cent of the value of the benefit given to the employees by the employers. One half of the total benefit will be absorbed in taxation. Of course, as Senator Sir John Carrick has said, it is a non-tax deduction. No deduction will be allowed for taxation purposes for the amounts which are paid in fringe benefits tax by the employers.

By any standards this Bill is unbelievably complex, it is heavy handed, and it will hit certain industries, in my view, so quickly, so badly and in such a devastating form that it may well cause their immediate collapse. The industries which will be hit hardest will be those which will be unable to pass on the increases in operating costs which this Bill will impose. It just so happens, thanks to the economic incompetence of this Government, that these are the industries that Australia needs now like never before. These are Australia's export industries, its mining industry and its farming industry. Any complex law is a difficult and dangerous thing even when it is being administered by competent legal practitioners. We have here, if I might presume to say, a Bill which is as complex as any which has ever been enacted by this Parliament, yet this Government expects employers, from the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd down to the scale of the small family butcher who provides free meat to his employees, the farmer who provides assistance by way of accommodation to his employees and the farmer who provides board and lodging to his beloved sons who are employees of the family company, in this complex maze of legislation to make their own assessment of their liability and to pay fringe benefits taxes accordingly. Should any of these small business people make a mistake-I believe that many of them will-they will find themselves in two predicaments: First of all, it is highly likely they will not have the liquidity to pay the tax and, secondly, particularly under this new draconian self-assessment system which this Government is seeking to cast upon the taxpayers, they will find themselves subject to very severe penalties.
This Bill represents yet another broken promise by the present Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. The fourth of the nine principles on which the Prime Minister said that taxation reform would be based is:
Any reform must lead to a simpler system, which therefore all Australians can easily understand.

This Bill is 139 pages long. There are 30 pages of definitions of specialised terms in the definition section of the Bill alone. There are countless other definitions which are to be found throughout the other clauses of the Bill. Some of the absolutely monstrous terms which employers will have to understand include: `Exclusive employee expense payment benefit', `extended travel residual payment benefit', and `in house residual fringe benefit'. The definition of the term `fringe benefit' contains something like 434 words made up of 26 paragraphs, 10 sub-paragraphs and five references to definitions in the Income Tax Assessment Act.

This Bill will also require people to keep detailed records. In the case of cars, a firm which is not prepared to have its tax liability determined by the arbitrary statutory formula which has been included in the legislation, it must keep detailed books of every single journey made by a vehicle and a driver. If a firm ever fails to keep a record of one short journey, that journey will be assumed to be a private journey and regarded as taxable. If any employer provides goods to an employee he must maintain records of the lowest price at which the goods were sold.

Should an employer have several employees use a house during the one year, he will be required to understand extremely complicated weighted average cost computations. That would probably confuse the brightest of the accountancy profession, never mind the poor little average businessman trying to solve his problems. The administrative difficulties created for business by this tax will, by any standards, be enormous. It seems that this Government just does not understand that the administrative costs associated with this tax represent a very significantly increased cost burden, in addition to the actual tax which will be cast upon the employers.

I believe that the enormous tax costs involved in making this tax workable is one of the reasons why the Treasurer is forcing employers to assess their own liability. In this way the Treasurer has achieved the amazing result of requiring employers to pay in order to learn how much tax they have to pay the Government. Of course, the other obvious and cynical reason is that the Government does not have the courage, the fortitude or the commitment to cast the tax--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean intestinal fortitude?

—Any sort of fortitude. To paraphrase what Senator Button is trying to say, the Government does not have the guts. The reason is that it is not prepared to take on the unions. It is not prepared to inflict upon itself the political odium of placing the tax where it ought to be, and that is upon the employees. Its natural constituents are immune. They are quarantined from this tax and from the responsibility of paying it. It is the poor old employers who are going to suffer again another kick from this Government. The Government wonders why we have the economic problems we have now. It just does not seem to understand what it is like to live in the real world.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take a look at the effects which the proposed fringe benefits tax will have on the economy in general terms. Now is not a bad time to do that. As a tax levied on the amount of benefits an employer gives to an employee, the most obvious effect of the fringe benefits tax will be on the price of labour. One might very well ask at the outset why a government which is presiding over a 7.9 per cent unemployment rate as a percentage of the labour force-based on the April figures-would even contemplate a measure which would result in increasing the price of labour. The reason escapes me except, of course, that most decisions of the Government of an economic nature seem to be made in a complete vacuum. The effects of this tax deserve more consideration. The tax will add to labour on-costs. These are the costs associated with the employment of labour apart from the actual money wages paid for productive effort. On-costs include annual leave commitments, sick leave, payroll tax, workers' compensation and a number of other non-cash forms of benefits or, as they are known now through this legislation, fringe benefits.

This Government has spent much of its time hailing the accord for allegedly containing the growth in direct payment to employees. It has not been prepared to discuss the considerable amounts which employers are paying in on-costs and the fact that this is one area of labour costs which is experiencing faster growth than money wages. That was demonstrated yesterday in the national accounts figures, which showed that total labour costs had increased by 6 per cent. Owing to the very nebulous nature of on-costs, precise statistics are always very difficult to obtain. But at the national wage case in August 1983, three employer groups presented estimates of on-costs as a percentage of direct labour costs. The Confederation of Australian Industry estimated that on-costs represented 35.3 per cent, the Metal Trades Industries Association Inc. estimated them at 38.6 per cent and the Australian Industries Development Association estimated them as being 43.1 per cent. The Confederation of Australian Industry has looked at the question of on-costs more recently. In the December 1985 issue of the Industrial Review the CAI estimated that total on-costs amounted to 36.6 per cent of direct wage payments. From 1983 to 1984, while direct wages increased by 8.5 per cent, on-costs increased by 10 per cent.

Not only do these figures indicate that many of the Government's claims about the accord are exaggerated or even spurious, but also they reveal that the area of on-costs already represents a significant cost to business. It is also an area which will be particularly adversely affected by the Government's fringe benefits measure. What is worse is that making the fringe benefits tax fall upon employers will result in enormous union pressure to receive remuneration increases in the form of fringe benefits rather than in cash, because the benefit is worth more in the hand and the responsibility for taxation lies not in the hands of the employee but in the hands of the employer. This is because anyone earning $19,501 per year or more is paying 46c in the dollar for every extra dollar earned. I might also say that average weekly earnings are presently $21,522.80 per year. Obviously there is a significant proportion of the work force with a strong incentive to take future wage rises as fringe benefits rather than as cash. When this occurs the employers will be forced to carry the cost not only of the fringe benefits but also of the 49 per cent tax. The employer will therefore pay almost 150 per cent of any benefit which he is forced to give to employees.

Another aspect which is likely to add to this cost pressure, as I have said before, is that fringe benefits are by nature very nebulous. As such, whatever might be the limiting effect of our increasingly irrelevant arbitration system in terms of money wages, it is bound to be even less effective in containing fringe benefit increases. One might well ask what the costs of this tax will be. The best estimates that I have been able to find-perhaps they are only indicative but they were the subject of a survey-indicate that the average increase in the cost of employing labour will be 2 per cent. The survey I refer to covered such industries as pharmaceuticals, retailers, merchant banks, transport, timber, shipping and mining-in other words, a pretty good cross-section. That demonstrates that the additional costs of labour will be in the range of 2 per cent. This 2 per cent rise in labour costs is indicative of the increase that will occur throughout the community. It will, of course, be in addition to the 3 per cent productivity increase and the national wage case increase to be expected, in the area of 2.3 per cent.

For a nation which is already thoroughly and hopelessly uncompetitive and which is running a current account deficit which could well exceed $14 billion in one year-this year, under this Government-this tax is a recipe, in my view, for an absolute economic disaster. It is yet another example of this Government being prepared to pursue policies as if it operated, as I said earlier, in a total vacuum, in total isolation. The Government's response, of course, would be to say that employers should simply switch from paying fringe benefits to paying employees in cash. In doing so the Government would again be displaying its utter ignorance of business realities. To do that would be to ignore the kind of union pressure about which I have just spoken. It would also be to ignore totally the regional differences throughout Australia. Pressure to pay fringe benefits taxes will be relatively less in the urban areas where there is ample housing, many community facilities and a large labour force. It will be relatively greater in the remoter parts of the country where there are none of these benefits.

The Confederation of Australian Industry indicated in its survey that mining companies paid benefits to their employees equivalent to 14.2 per cent of the amount the employees were paid in wages. Although agriculture was not surveyed by the CAI, it is quite reasonable to expect that it operates in very much the same environment and conditions and that it, too, pays a very significant part of its wages through fringe benefits, relative to the total wage costs. For both agriculture and mining, provision of employee benefits such as housing is not, in my view, the payment of a perk but an absolutely essential precondition for being able to operate. It is an essential precondition for attracting labour into the areas involved, particularly the mining areas, where the employees are required to live in very harsh, isolated, unpleasant and difficult areas. A similar difficulty, of course, impinges on small business and on isolated councils. In this process of attracting employees to remote areas companies have established whole towns and have contributed enormously to remote area development. This is generally, I must say, much to the relief of the treasuries of the various State governments and, of course, the Federal Government, because they have not had to meet any of the infrastructure costs of building in these towns which they might have otherwise been required to do. One has to ask: Where would Port Hedland, Karratha, Dampier, Tom Price, Mount Newman, Pannawonica and Paraburdoo be now? Those towns just would not exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would be in Canberra.

—They would be in Canberra, yes. They just would not exist; yet they represent, as part of the mining industry, very nearly 40 per cent of Australia's export earnings. Mining companies such as Western Mining Corporation Ltd have on their books stocks of between 1,600 and 1,700 homes in towns such as Kambalda which just would not be there; the Government could not carry the burden of providing the infrastructure.
—This is very interesting, Senator, but what is the point you are trying to make?

—The point I am trying to make is that the Government is now casting a fringe benefit tax upon mining companies for providing housing accommodation which could not have been afforded in the first place by the employees and least of all by the Government. If they had not built the homes the towns would not be there, the industry would not be there and the export earnings would not be there.
—That is exactly what you did in government except that you did not have the guts to go on with it-to use your terminology.

—That is quite untrue, Senator Button. We did not cast a fringe benefit tax on employees. At one stage in a moment of temporary aberration the then Treasurer flirted with the idea that we might have a modest tax on housing in some of these isolated areas, but he soon learnt the mistake; he soon recanted and retracted. At least he had the courage, the brains and the common sense to recognise the inherent danger of the course he was taking and very quickly withdrew. Common sense prevailed in his case, but the Labor Party crashes on; it carries on; it is going to make a mistake, come hell or high water, and nobody is going to stop it.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the contribution of farmers and miners to Australian development, the Government intends to hit them with this fringe benefit tax, this diabolical fringe benefits tax-screw a few more bucks out of the rich multinationals. I suppose that is what it thinks it is doing. In my view such a tax would be inappropriate at any time. At the best of times it is inappropriate, but, of course, the Government is displaying its usual finesse for total insensitivity and is imposing the tax at perhaps the worst time, at a time when the mining industry and the rural industry need all the support they can get, not the impost of further costs. Australia as never before requires a dynamic mining industry and a dynamic agricultural industry. By way of example, in April the nation spent $1,476m more than it earned. It is expected that by the end of this financial year the Government will have presided over a current account deficit of $14 billion or about $888 for every man, woman and child in this country.

In 1984-85 the mining and agricultural industries together accounted for 72 per cent of Australia's export earnings. Despite this fact and our obvious present need for export income, the Federal Government intends to hit these sectors with this fringe benefits tax. As I have already said, the mining industry pays the equivalent of 14.2 per cent of wages in the form of benefits. This means that when the 49 per cent tax is imposed, even allowing for the remote area concessions under this Bill, modest as they are, I might say, the tax will still mean a rise in costs equivalent to a 4.2 per cent increase in wages. A 4.2 per cent increase. Not even the present Government would be silly enough to support that before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, but through this insidious form of taxation it is prepared to have it cast upon the employers.

As average wages paid to mining employees in November 1984 were something in the range of $30,420 per year, the fringe benefits tax could well mean a rise in costs of $1,270 per employee per year. The Government means to access fringe benefits tax on remote area housing based on-of course it always does these things in the most complicated way-a most complicated formula of the percentage of national consumption expenditure on housing applied to average mining wages. As average national expenditure on housing is about 20 per cent and average mining industry wages are something in the range of $30,000 per year, the Government is assuming that the housing is worth about $6,000 to each employee by way of benefit. Even if this is reduced by the intended remote area concession of 40 per cent and the tax rate is applied at 49 per cent, which it will be very shortly, the liability would be, as I say, about $1,764 per house. That is to be incurred by way of fringe benefits tax cast upon the employers; that is, if there is no contribution by the employees of course. Thus, the liability for fringe benefits tax will be cast upon the employers of the mining sector and the agricultural sector in a very onerous way.

Of course, the tax comes at a time when the industries are in absolutely no shape to absorb these extra burdens. Both are price takers on world markets. They cannot simply pass on their additional and ever rising costs to their consumers, because they do not control the prices. They are subject to the fluctuations and variations of world supply and demand, which of course dictate world prices and the prices they receive. Senator Button would well know that the mining industry is presently in a very low cycle. Base metal prices are depressed, more depressed probably than they have been for a very long time. Net profit as a percentage of shareholders' funds--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not as depressed as I am after listening to you for half an hour.
—Well, if listening to me and hearing the facts depresses Senator Button, I only hope that, like Saul on the road to Damascus, he repents and repents quickly, and does something about it.
—He has to see the light first before he repents.
—Well, a burning bush would not change Senator Button, I am quite sure.
—Senator Button knows he is wrong.

—That is right. He is not Saul and he will not see the burning bush, but he is Pontius Pilate, washing his hands of it. He has obviously learnt a few sins from the Bible-not much virtue but a few sins. The net profit as a percentage of shareholders' funds invested in the mining sector last year was only 5.7 per cent across all the mining sector, and that in itself is indicative of the difficulty that that industry is in. What person would be investing in the mining sector, with a 5.7 per cent return, when under this Government one can go to a bank and get a three-month bank bill at around about 19 per cent? The National Australia Bank indicated in its February monthly summary that foreign investment in-flow into mining had fallen from a peak of $3,024m in 1979-80 and has not been more than $350m in any year since, and is falling.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the fringe benefits tax will be yet another impost by this Government on the Australian farmer. It will be another Hawke Government imposed cost increase which, of course, will lead to farm incomes falling further. Returns on rural investment already have plummeted to minus 6.2 per cent. One only has to look at the difficulties of various sectors of the rural economy to see that this is so. For example, the average wheat farmer now receives minus $7,500 per year by way of income. The Government is asking him to absorb something in the range of another $2,000 in taxes. I ask Senator Button how he thinks farmers will pay that? Surely even Senator Button's arithmetic adds up to the inevitable conclusion that those farmers will not be able to do so. I hope that all honourable senators will remember this measure when the Government attempts to blame all Australia's rural problems on overseas factors-as the Government invariably seems to have done in the past.

I have discussed the impact of the fringe benefits tax on the economy generally. In particular I have discussed its impact on the two remote area industries of mining and agriculture on which, I believe, there will be the most dramatic impact. Time does not permit me to go into any detail on the many other areas of the economy on which this tax will have a damaging effect. However, if I did have time I would talk about the motor vehicle industry, which Senator Button seems to have some little knowledge of. The difficulties of that industry, of course, stand out starkly when we see that the new vehicle registration figures for February 1986 were 27.6 per cent lower than for February 1985. This is due in part to the high interest rate policy of this Government. In addition Senator Button has been asked on a number of occasions to quantify the various reasons for the decline. On each occasion he chooses to avoid an answer. He knows the answer but he is not prepared to commit himself to the truth. I have not had time to detail other areas of course but I will do so in the Committee stages of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Somewhere along the line during this debate on the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax Bill 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Bill 1986 and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986 we seem to have lost track of the fact that they correct an inequity, a rort, an anomaly, a hiccup, call it what you like, in the taxation system which has allowed more and more people to avoid paying tax through being recipients of fringe benefits. Those people are, in the main, those on relatively high incomes. Even Mr Howard, as reported in this morning's Australian newspaper, was forced to acknowledge the fact that areas of undoubted abuse exist in relation to certain fringe benefits. If employers and some employees allow fringe benefits to be abused then they have only themselves to blame when governments take some action to correct the problem-the loss of tax revenue and so on, certainly, the loss of equity-that is caused by this.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us face it, Madam Acting Deputy President nobody-not you, not me, no honourable senator in here and certainly, none of the people out there-likes paying tax. I think that the two things that Australians grizzle about most are paying taxes, which they perceive as being too high, and the way that governments spend that tax revenue when they get it. That is a simple fact of life. We do not like paying taxes. However, more importantly I would say that the person who pays his or her fair share of tax-often that person is not in any position to do otherwise of course-resents very much the fact that there are a percentage of people in this country who are able to get around the tax system one way or another.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Western Australian Liberal Party is full of them. That is why we had so much vehemence from the last senator.
—Whom does John Horgan work for now? You vilified him two years ago. He works for the Mafia over there now, the Burke State Government.

—I am grateful for the assistance that my colleagues on both sides of the House are giving in this. The point that Senator Button raises is probably partly due at least to the fact that certain honourable senators are protesting too much, shall we say, about some of the legislation that is before us today, some of the legislation that has been before us in past months and legislation which is still to be debated. The fact is that the fringe benefits tax is about equity, pure and simple. If Senator Sir John Carrick believes that the argument that we, the Australian Democrats, have been putting as a reason for supporting this legislation is particularly ugly, which is the term that he used, then I am afraid that that is a problem that he has rather than one that I have. I do not see an argument in support of equity in the taxation system as being particularly ugly. In fact, I see it as being particularly fair. Whatever the whinges of Opposition members and some well-off members of the business community may indicate to the contrary, the general public realises that tax equity is behind all this and supports the legislation in its entirety. A number of people have suggested, I think more in hope than anything else, that I and my colleagues may well lose our seats as a consequence of supporting this legislation.
—What would we do without you, Senator Haines?

—Senator Crichton-Browne is too kind. I just say that, in the unlikely event of my losing my seat as a consequence of supporting equity in taxation, then I will do so at least knowing that I have done something more useful, moral and right than most honourable senators achieve in this place in more years than I have been here.
—You won't lose your seat, you will come back with a bigger majority. It is Senator Crichton-Browne who will be in trouble.

—I suspect that the people who ring me up and say that they will never vote for me again have never voted for me in the past. As Senator Button said, I am hardly likely to lose a large percentage of my vote because I am supporting something which is equitable and moral. Unquestionably it is outrageous that the majority of workers who receive remuneration only by way of salary and wages are forced to pay tax on that because they have no means of avoiding or evading that tax while a bunch of reasonably well-off executives or members of senior management can get away with paying limited tax because their remuneration package is part salary, part perk or part fringe benefit. I ask honourable senators to tell people out in the community who are on average weekly earnings or less and who are paying tax on that, in accord with the rules of the tax system, it is equitable for somebody on a salary of $40,000 a year plus a $25,000 car to pay tax only on the cash income, so to speak, of that package. The present system clearly is inequitable and most people are aware of that.
—What about the mine workers in the Pilbara?
—Order! I ask Senator Crichton-Browne to cease interjecting.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, the gnat in the background is not causing too much of a problem. If companies do not like paying the tax and if they believe that employees should be paying it, then there is a very simple action that they can take that will put that into effect. The solution is quite simple: Instead of the company giving the employee a car, an overseas trip, a low interest bank loan or writing off debts, or whatever the perk happens to be, it can increase the salary or the wage commensurate with the value of the perk and let the employee purchase the car, pay a reasonable amount on the loan, or buy the overseas trip. In so doing, that employee will then pay a fair and equitable tax on the salary package that he or she has.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as screams from various sectors to the effect that the new fringe benefits tax will destroy the car industry and, suggestions that it already has, are concerned, let me point out that the drop in motor vehicle registrations in the first months of this year is due almost entirely to the record car sales of last year. If the turn- around in the April figures is anything to go by it indicates that the drop was temporary at that. Anybody who has made any attempt to look at the situation in order to see exactly what impact the threat of the fringe benefits tax may have on the car industry will have discovered that motor vehicle registrations for 1985 were an absolute record. They were a record compared even to the record figures for 1984. Anybody who can add up and who knows how many people buy cars must be able to work out-this applies to even the simple minds in the Liberal Party-that one cannot continue to follow years of record purchases of cars with additional years of record purchases. In fact, though there was a drop in the January figures that was marginal on previous January figures, the motor industry statistics service indicates that there has now been a 14 per cent increase in passenger car sales from March 1986. The pattern of car sales and car registrations going up and down is repeating itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is going down and down.
—No. If the honourable senator will listen, he may let the facts get in the way of a good argument.
—You quoted the March figures. The April figures are now out.

—The April figures are 14 per cent up on the March figures. The motor industry statistics service indicates that and I have no doubt that they will continue to rise. If those figures are anything to go by, the impact of the FBT on car sales will be absolutely negligible. Throughout this debate the Australian Democrats' main concerns have been, first of all, with the introduction of equity into the taxation system-something which has been missing for a privileged section of the community for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: The second issue was the effect on the Button car plan of the fringe benefits tax levels which the Government originally planned to impose. The effect was to be felt much more in South Australia than in any other State. I am delighted to have received the support of my colleagues from other States on this issue-support that was singularly lacking from Labor senators from South Australia, to say nothing of Labor senators from other States. It is ludicrous for a government to establish a plan over a period of eight years which sets out to introduce some sort of sanity into an industry like the car industry, and for it then part of the way through the plan to inject something which could possibly have an unwarranted impact on it. The changes we have had made to the scales the Government originally planned to impose appear, if industry sources are any indication, to have taken that concern out of their minds. Indeed, in this morning's Australian is a comment by the Executive Director of the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries, Mr Ian Grigg, who has welcomed the rate structure changes for the tax on company cars. He said:
The lessening of the company car tax will help the automotive industry at an appropriate time when sales, particularly of fleet vehicles, have been severely retarded.
If one looks at last year's figures, one will see that they have been severely retarded, because of the increased number of sales that occurred in 1985.

The other issue we were particularly concerned about was the unwarranted impact that this tax was expected to have on charitable institutions-organisations that aim to provide relief from poverty for those people who are in economic difficulties, organisations which supply services to people with disabilities. Organisations such as the Royal Blind Society of New South Wales, the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of the Disabled, the New South Wales Society for Crippled Children, the Queensland Deaf Society, the Victorian Deaf Society, Bedford Industries in South Australia and various other organisations do not need to be hit any harder by something like a fringe benefits tax. We have prepared an amendment that will exempt charitable organisations, as indeed the Government had already indicated that it would exempt religious organisations. Charitable institutions, those public benevolent institutions that operate in Australia and provide services for people who are in poverty or who are in need in some other way, need have no fear that the fringe benefits tax will affect them in any way at all.

Some interesting comments have been passed in the last few days about the effect the tax is likely to have on people in certain religious orders. Certainly this also concerned the Democrats, because it appeared from the way in which the legislation was drafted that the only people who were likely to get any benefit from an exemption were those in the two major religions, namely, the Roman Catholic and Anglican churches. A good deal of concern has been expressed to us-from, for example, the Uniting Church, which does not have ordained clergy and operates very largely through the use of lay preachers, and from the Salvation Army, which again does not ordain its ministers but commissions them-that they would be unduly affected. The First Assistant Commissioner of Taxation has set out in a letter that is probably available to most people that this is not likely to be the case. Inter alia, he said in the letter:

The test for exemption is whether the benefit (the use of a car) is provided principally in respect of pastoral duties or other duties or activities directly related to the practice, study, teaching or propagation of religious beliefs. If that test is satisfied, as it would be in the ordinary case of a clergyman working in a parish, the occasional use of the car for other than `pastoral' pursuits would be irrelevant.

An associated matter raised by the Uniting Church is whether Lay Pastors would be treated in the same way as ordained clergy for FBT purposes. Lay Pastors may act in the place of an ordained Minister in the event of a ministerial vacancy and are otherwise appointed to assist a Minister.
He continued:
. . . fringe benefits provided to the Lay Pastor principally in respect of pastoral duties would be exempt while the Lay Pastor continued to act in the capacity of a Minister.

The absurd suggestion made by Senator Crichton- Browne by way of interjection during Senator Sir John Carrick's speech that somehow manses were not to be exempt is a nonsense because they are picked up under the broad exemption for religious organisations.

Some National Farmers Federation members have been contacting my office complaining that they will now have to pay tax on their own homes and their own cars. The fact is that they will not have to pay such tax. If they own their homes and if they own their cars, there is no more problem than there is, Mr Acting Deputy President, for you or me owning a home or owning a car. If, however, they have formed some elaborate company structure and it is the company that owns the home and the car, quite likely they will find that that company will pay tax on it, and so it should. If they have gone into some sort of system to avoid paying tax in the past, quite legally avoiding paying that tax, they will be picked up by this equally legal measure which will make those companies face up to the fact that fringe benefits will now no longer be tax exempt.

I have also had a number of calls this morning from farmers who are not particularly worried about the fringe benefits tax and, in the main, have said they support tax equity, but they are worried because somebody has told them they will have to pay tax on the eggs their hens produce and the food they provide to their families and themselves. Again, this is a nonsense. Ordinary family farmers will not have to do this. The only people who will are the ones who in the past have been part of an elaborate company structure and have been claiming as tax deductions the food they have eaten or have provided to their families. If they have done this in the past-and it is something that very few families in this country can do-they are quite likely to be hit under this legislation.

There have also been allegations that board and lodgings that small business people give to their children working in a family business will be taxed-that the bedroom a son or daughter sleeps in will suddenly become a fringe benefit. I think that I am long past being surprised at the number of people who do not read legislation. However, I would have thought that in this case it would have been sensible to look at just exactly what a fringe benefit comprises before people started making those sorts of statements. The criterion for taxing a benefit is whether or not the possession of that benefit arose out of the recipient's employment. Presumably the bedroom that the son or daughter of a small business person sleeps in is provided because that person is a member of the family and not in the main because that person happens to be working as part of that small business. Therefore, anybody who is going around stirring up trouble in the hearts and minds of people who have their children working for them during the holidays is quite mistaken as far as the effect that that is likely to have on those people is concerned.

Senator Sir John Carrick raised what I thought was a particularly interesting point in his speech a little earlier this morning. He pointed out that everyone who damages production in this country damages Australia and the Australian economy. Senator Crichton-Browne went one step further-I think it was he; certainly others have done so-and mentioned the problem that Australia faces with its balance of payments difficulties. I suggest, then, that it ought to be remembered that every person in this country who drives a Rolls Royce, Volvo, Jaguar, BMW or other imported car is damaging Australia's economy-certainly doing so is damaging the production of local cars, and unquestionably it is contributing to the imbalance that we currently see in Australia's balance of payments in our trade deficit. Therefore, I suggest that they look to themselves, that these businessmen who complain about foreign debts, the balance of trade and payments problems look to see exactly what is their contribution in the way of the things that they produce, the cars they drive, the leather coats that they wear, and stop whining about other areas.

The point that we ought to be facing today is simply this: A fringe benefit tax is a matter of tax equity-it is that, pure and simple. If our argument that this legislation deserves support because it is equitable is considered ugly by Senator Sir John Carrick-`ugly' was the word he used-I am afraid that I cannot help that. The majority of Australians simply do not agree with him. The majority of Australians-who are on wages and salaries-resent deeply, and quite rightly, that there are some people in this country who are in a position to avoid paying tax and who are able to have a higher standard of living simply because they can make deals and come to arrangements with their employers so that their remuneration package is made up partly of salary on which they pay tax and partly by receiving a car or some other fringe benefit on which they do not pay tax. The argument starts and finishes there with tax equity, and I for one am pleased to be able to support that approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to follow Senator Haines in this debate on the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill, the Fringe Benefits Tax Bill, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Bill and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. Until she had spoken I could not understand the intellectual processes that went on in the Australian Democrats' minds in the way they had, in fact, decided to take their quaint broking position in the middle and negotiated, clearly, what they thought was to their political advantage in this matter rather than what was in the best interests of the Australian people. I was interested to hear that Senator Haines was clearly basing her view on an inability to understand statistics. She said that there were simply ups and downs in the motor vehicle registration area, for example. I would have thought that Senator Haines, in particular, would have paid greater attention to the concerns of the motor industry as, of course, the South Australian economy, which she is supposed to represent here, is heavily dependent upon that industry.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of introduction to the burden of what I wish to say, it is worth mentioning that, while Senator Haines concentrated on a slight upturn in the April figures for registration of new motor vehicles, she failed to mention that after taking into account the modest increase in April sales over March sales the overall market for the first four months of 1986 is still 22 per cent down on last year. Therefore, here we have a slight pickup after three disastrous and consecutive falls in the first quarter of 1986-we have a slight hiccup, if you like-and Senator Haines jumps on that as some extraordinary and remarkable piece of evidence to support her view that the motor industry is not being severely damaged, that jobs are not being put at enormous risk, that the industry is not being clobbered, and that everything in the South Australian garden is lovely. In fact, her deliberate exclusion of the facts-particularly the fact that, even taking what she said into account, sales for the first four months were still 22 per cent down on last year's figures-I believe, is quite intolerable. It appears to me to reflect the basis on which the Australian Democrats have been able to come to their curious conclusion that they should support the Government in ramming through this offensive, unfair and, of course, massively unwise tax at a time when the Australian economy is already suffering, without these added disincentives to business.

It seems appropriate that, having heard Senator Haines from South Australia, we should then hear what the Labor Premier of South Australia has to say about these matters. Earlier this month Mr Bannon attended in Canberra the Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries annual dinner, which he addressed. I will quote in part what that Labor Premier had to say at that dinner about the impact on the motor industry of this tax package:

I had hoped to be able to address you tonight in the knowledge that the Federal Government had accepted the arguments put forward by the automotive industry, unions and various governments to change the proposed fringe benefits tax plans in relation to motor cars. Unfortunately, however, I am addressing you in the knowledge that a decision has been taken which will prove detrimental to the car industry and one which will have severe ramifications for my state in particular.

I interpose that that is also Senator Haines's State and, if the evidence she has given today of her concern for her State is reflected in any of her other activities in this chamber, I hope that at the next election the people of South Australia will take a different view of her right to represent them. Mr Bannon continued:

I am particularly disappointed that the Federal Government was unable to show the flexibility to change its plans as this was an issue which was not being opposed on purely sectional grounds. Governments, unions and industry itself have all come to the same conclusion; namely, that the fringe benefits tax in its proposed form would have a detrimental effect on the car industry in Australia. The Federal Government had been presented with rational arguments and demonstrable evidence that this was so.
This is a strong, well argued case from the Labor Premier of South Australia, who continued later:
What made the Federal Government's decision even more disappointing was the fact that at no stage were we opposing the principle of tax reform but rather the method by which it was introduced.

The Premier of South Australia is complaining, quite properly, that rational argument and demonstrable evidence were ignored or wiped aside by the Federal Government in its determination to proceed with this tax, which is massively damaging to this particular industry.

I also am concerned about the impact that this tax is having on the motor vehicle industry because of its flow-on consequences. As a senator for New South Wales, I am keen to look after the interests of the steel cities of New South Wales-in particular, Wollongong, where I have my office, and Newcastle. I have been conducting some inquiries to establish what will be the impact on our steel industry of the sorts of falls in motor vehicle sales and production that are an inevitable consequence of the damage that is being done, and will continue to be done, to the motor vehicle industry as a result of this tax. We have already seen so far in the first four months of this year a 22 per cent fall in motor vehicle sales-according, of course, to the industry's statistics service, Idaps. This will continue. A Martec (Australia) Limited forecast indicates that vehicle registrations will fall from 700,000 in 1985 to about 598,000 in 1986-about a 15 per cent fall. It is true that this fall will not be due entirely to expectations of reduced sales because of the fringe benefits tax on company cars. It will also be due in part to the sharp increase in motor vehicle prices because of the depreciation of the Australian dollar which, of course, has emerged as a direct result of the Government's economic policies.

The interesting thing about these figures is not simply that there will be a 15 per cent fall. Sales of fleet cars to businesses-I refer in particular to Australian made cars such as Commodores and Falcons-are expected to be depressed. Combined registrations of those two models are forecast to fall by approximately 17 per cent during this year. Let us think of the implications of that for the steel industry, because sheet steel demand by motor vehicle companies is expected to fall to 122,500 tonnes in 1986, compared with 140,000 tonnes in 1985. That is a fall of approximately 13 per cent in sheet steel usage, partly as a result of this tax-in fact, largely as a result of this tax along with the devaluation.

The situation for local producers of steel is even worse than those figures suggest because imports of sheet steel, which also, of course, are used in car making in Australia, are generally supplied on a fixed quantity basis. This results, of course, in any changes in demand being reflected by more violent fluctuations in the demand for Australian produced steel. I have been supplied with a forecast that shows that sales of locally produced automotive sheet steel will fall by in excess of 20 per cent because of this assault on the Australian motor vehicle industry by this Government through its curious economic policies that have produced this disastrous balance of payment situation but in particular and specifically this fringe benefits tax belting.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many jobs will that cost?

—Indeed, as Senator Messner says, how many jobs will that cost? I raise this matter as well because there is no doubt that the motor vehicle industry is massively concerned about the impact on jobs. I will deal later with how many jobs are at risk because of this measure. It is of major concern that any falls in the sales of fleet cars-as I said, Commodores and Falcons maintain the highest local steel content-will have a disproportionate impact, a compounding and depressing impact, on sheet steel demand. That is very bad news for Newcastle and Wollongong, and for the Australian steel industry which, as members of the Government no doubt are aware, is still struggling to recover from the depressed conditions which resulted in the creation of a steel industry arrangement and at last some increasing stability in that industry. All those efforts are now being hit by this kind of tax on an industry which has been struggling to restore itself. When people say it does not matter; it is only the motor vehicle industry that is being affected, they do not recognise the flow-on consequences to industries such as the Australian steel industry, which is a basic industry and a major employer in Newcastle and Wollongong.

SPEECH.PARA: I am becoming more and more convinced that the Government simply has not done its sums on the consequences in other areas of collecting its millions of dollars in the fringe benefits tax on motor cars. Some work has been done which suggests that the net gain for the Government will be very small because of the depressing impact that it will have, for example, on other government revenue.
