What will happen to sales tax collections on motor vehicles, which go to the government, if its fringe benefits tax substantially reduces the volume of motor vehicle sales-and therefore, of course, the volume of sales tax collected?

So we have continuing and widening evidence of the disastrous impact of this measure. A director of the accounting firm of Ibis-Deloitte Haskins and Sells has made some interesting revelations and estimates about the impact of this kind of tax on a whole range of businesses and areas of employment. He stated this week:

. . . fringe benefits would cut business profits more than 4 per cent in 1986-87 and more than 6 per cent in 1987-88 . . . most companies would absorb the impact of the legislation rather than diminish the earnings of their managers and executives.

Many people might say that it does not matter a darn that company profits should be diminished-perhaps because it has been alleged by this Government that, because companies are enjoying a much improved profit situation, it is quite reasonable to knock off some of this advantage that they are getting. But this is basically a myth. It is a myth that business's share of gross domestic product is at the highest level for 10 years and that business is in good enough shape to absorb these new taxes. It must be remembered that these fringe benefits taxes will be paid by the employer, not the employee. They will be added to the costs of business at a time, of course, when Australia is struggling to hold down its relative costs and at a time when Australia's inflation rate is at a relatively record level compared with those of its trading partners.

Let me get back to the impact on profits and this myth that the Government is spreading that the business profit share of gross domestic product is the highest it has been for 10 years. The reality is that, when one combines the after tax profits of companies, unincorporated enterprises and public enterprises, the figure is now much lower, as a share of GDP, than it was in 1980 or 1981. Too often reference is made only to the companies' share, ignoring unincorporated enterprises, whose share has collapsed over the last decade and which will also be seriously affected by this tax. The director of the accounting firm I mentioned, whose name is Mr Adolph Hanich, stated:

To compound the problem, reference is usually made to the term gross operating surplus, which equates with gross profits before depreciation, interest and taxes. The net profit picture is vastly different . . . when these other items are taken into account.
There is no doubt that business profits have been, and will continue to be, under a fair amount of competitive pressure when all these matters are taken into account.

The other point I wanted to make out of Mr Hanich's speech which he is giving around Australia to the many people who are massively concerned about the impact of this tax is that there will be a tendency-this is a serious matter for employment-for many firms to sub-contract a number of services rather than carry full time staff. No doubt this will result in some middle management being sacked to help offset a reduction of profits. Thus we can see a clear indication of rising unemployment as a result of this kind of tax. Mr Hanich also makes the sound point that not all industries will raise prices to cover the effects of a fringe benefits tax, but the impact on inflation if they did raise prices would be about 0.3 per cent next year and about 0.7 per cent in 1987-88. It is interesting to think that at a time when we are already at our relative worst position on inflation compared with that in the rest of the world, the Government is talking about a set of taxes which have a direct inflationary impact of adding 0.7 per cent to our inflation rate which is already 9.2 per cent-according to the consumer price index-in a full year.

The other point I think is well worth making is that, while these new taxes will represent in 1987-88 only about 1.5 per cent of the Federal tax revenue, the collection costs and the disruption to business will be very high indeed. That matter has been raised here by many other speakers today. It is on the questions of who will be affected and what inflation impacts there will be that I think it is worth referring to a few other matters, for example, the airline industry. Only a couple of days ago there was a report in a newspaper that the Government has simply failed to respond to a very serious proposition put up by the airline industry which is trying to remove some of the enormous administrative costs that will be incurred by it. The Board of Airline Representatives of Australia, which represents over 40 airlines, has spelt out what will happen if these proposals are implemented. It said that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, had not bothered to communicate with it. The airline group came to the conclusion that the fringe benefit tax among airline employees would probably cost between $10m and $15m a year. Of course out of that amount something between $7m and $10m a year will be paid by two government airlines; that is, the Government will pay from one pocket into another. However, the net amount that the remainder of the industry would be talking about is somewhere between $5m and $7m which will go to the Government. Obviously someone will have to pay that, and no doubt that will be the consumer again, which, of course, will be inflationary. The point I want to make on this matter is that while the tax will raise only about $5m to $7m in tax for the Government, it will cost both the Government and the airlines millions of dollars to collect. This cost of collection is just absurd. That is why the airline organisation stated:
And we think that is exactly why our very simple, very fair flat-tax proposal-
It is saying that it will pay just $300 a year for each airline employee to the Government rather than have to fill out all the administrative nonsense that will go on.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could do it with cars too.

—They could do the same with cars, as Senator Messner said. Instead of that, the airlines have this major administrative nonsense which will not only cost the Government a lot, and, of course, increase the volume of public servants-it appears that this Government's greatest approach to resolving unemployment is to put on more public servants-but also involve the industry itself in enormous costs. We have to recognise that with regard to the airlines this is not a tax which will hit rich, fat businessmen who drive their Mercedes. This is one of the arrant pieces of nonsense being spread by the Government and the Australian Democrats. The people who are recipients of the so-called naughty fringe benefits in this case are stewardesses, stewards, hosties-they are not rich people by any means-and ordinary airline employees, clerks and so on. These are the people whose fringe benefits are either at risk or will have to be paid for by the employer which means by the people who buy airline tickets, by the people who travel, by the ordinary people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There was another report. Even the cost of dying will become more expensive as a result of the fringe benefits tax, according to a Sydney funeral director who said that the fringe benefit tax provisions would add substantial cost to funeral services largely, of course, because of the impact they will have on those employees who are required to provide a 24-hour service and naturally are required to live on the premises. So this tax will have a wide-ranging and disastrous impact. It will have an impact on inflation as I have demonstrated. It will be a major discouragement to investment and growth, as we have seen. It will reduce output in some industries. It will have a huge administrative cost, but before I proceed to that matter I should mention that the fact that anything should be aimed at diminishing investment is totally disastrous at a time when this week we have seen sets of figures showing that investment in Australia has been seriously affected by this Government's economic policies. It is at a time when the Treasurer, only recently in his extraordinary interview with Mr John Laws, at last said truthfully, honestly and earnestly that the Australian economy was in a hole, stressed that it was absolutely vital to cut government spending in order to allow private sector investment to go ahead.

Unless private sector investment goes ahead we will not be able to produce the goods in Australia that will allow us to reduce our imports and therefore increase the strength of our balance of payments current account and get us out of the hole that this Government's policies have pushed us into. Yet, in the latest figures we have no evidence of any strength in investment in Australia. On the contrary, this week's statistics showed that after adjusting for inflation and seasonal factors private sector investment declined by 2.1 per cent in the March quarter following its fall of 3.3 per cent in the December quarter. It is not expected there will be any recovery.

Last night we saw the astounding national income figures which dramatised even further the disastrous fall in investment in Australia which is continuing and which will keep us heavily in hock. We face all of these problems. We have reduced economic activity as a result of these taxes. The sorts of points that are being made by speakers on the Opposition side who have covered a whole range of industries are, for example, those raised last night by Senator Vanstone who dealt with the impact of the fringe benefit tax on employee accommodation and meals in the hotel and motel industry in Australia. As she pointed out, this tax will have an impact on the nation's hotel and motel tariffs and charges by an average of 9.6 per cent. The motel industry said that this imposition will force hotels and motels around Australia to generate this additional revenue in order just to pay the so-called in-house fringe benefits. We have such examples all around us.

The Opposition has made a case covering the whole range of Australian industries. I have pointed out the hidden impact on major industries such as steel. All we hear from the Government is that the tax is necessary because there has been a tax ripoff and it must be ended. In other words, the baby has to go out with the bath water. One must hammer in the tack with an enormous mallet; it does not matter what else one destroys as one hammers down that tack.

Clearly, the correct answer is not what the Government has in mind. Clearly, the correct answer is to fix up the whole of the Income Tax Assessment Act. But this Government is not fixing that Act which, with its 1,100 pages, is already far too big. It is adding something like one-third to it in this package of Bills. It is an incredible addition. We are to have a one-third increase in the size of the Act, yet speakers from the Government side have said that this will increase the simplicity of the Act. That is absolute nonsense. What we clearly need is a total review of the whole taxation situation in Australia. I remind the Government that that is what its Treasurer set out to do last year. He was blocked and obstructed, basically by the trade union movement in Australia and by his colleagues.

TALK.START.PARA: —His colleagues.

—Exactly. As my good friend from Tasmania says, it was his colleagues in particular who blocked the Treasurer's attempts to do what the Opposition is and always has been strongly recommending-a total revision of all the madnesses that have been forced to be developed in the tax Act. To have this sort of piecemeal, nonsensical approach that this Government is taking, which will increase by one-third the number of pages of tax law in an already obese tax Act, is arrant nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is on the wrong track. That explains why it is simply dishonest of members of the Government to say that the Opposition is endeavouring to block this legislation because it is trying to protect tax rip-offs. That is absolute nonsense. One of the reasons the tax Act is 1,100 pages thick is that we have had to keep adding enormous amounts of tax law to it to block evident rip-offs. If this Government were fair dinkum, it would have done what the Treasurer tried to do last year but was blocked from doing, which was to reduce the incidence of direct tax from people's pay and to increase the indirect tax element-which has been Opposition policy for years; in other words, make the tax system fairer and more simple. This Government has not done that in this legislation. It is seeking to hit specific industries to raise money for one simple reason. It has to raise extra money because it does not have the intestinal fortitude to cut its own spending. Mr Keating cannot get his Ministers to reduce their Government spending. As a result of his and the Government's abysmal failure to act responsibly, the Government has to raise more money. Unfortunately, the manner in which it is doing so is seriously hitting industries and employment throughout Australia. The Opposition is strongly resisting this and demands a total review of the extraordinary tax situation which exists in Australia right now. That certainly will be our policy in government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax Bill 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Bill 1986 and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986. At the outset I should point out that the net gain from this tax has been calculated to be very small indeed, yet its cost of operation, particularly to the private sector, will be horrendous. I believe it will have a disastrous impact on the costs for small businesses and will thus become a tax on employment. It is obvious to me that most members of the Australian Labor Party, who are either union officials or pedantic academics, have never run a small business. I do not believe they could run a cake stall. If they believe that these taxes will do anything other than destroy the small businesses that are attempting to make a profit in this country, it just shows how senseless many of them are. There are 56 pages in the little book of new rules that has been sent out, incidentally, before we have passed this legislation, to businesses around the country.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is full of difficulties. A tremendous number of forms will have to be filled out and kept. It will lead to a bonanza for accountants. I do not think I have had one letter from accountants about this legislation, because they can see how much it will help them. We will have an accountant-led recovery in this country if this legislation goes through in its present form.

TALK.START.PARA: —That book would not even be accurate.

—Senator Watson is exactly right. I was just coming to that. The Government could not even get its little book right. It has issued a full page of changes to it. They are not little changes; there are 15 of them. For instance, one of the corrections is the following to paragraph 3.6.1:

SPEECH.PARA: Replace the words `two thirds' in the third line of page 14 with the words `three quarters'.
What kind of dill wrote this stuff and made errors like that? What other errors are there in the book that have not yet been found? Another amendment, to paragraph 9.2.1, states:
All references to 52.5% should read 37.5%.

They are not just typographical errors; they are errors that no government should allow to get out. If I were employing somebody who put out a book like that, I would sack him. Thank goodness I am not employing the people who are working for the Government. That book, in its present form, should be withdrawn and properly printed, particularly if we make any amendments to the legislation before us today. What is the good in having the book floating around? I wonder how much it cost to send it out to everybody in this country. If honourable senators try to read the book they will find it most time consuming. It is not written in an easy way for people to understand. For argument's sake, the fringe benefits tax on cars takes six full pages to explain, in addition to references to it in other places. When one sees what rubbish has to be detailed, one realises that just what I said earlier is true: this tax was dreamt up by people who have no idea of running a business and, I believe, no idea of reality. The difficulties and annoyance of keeping the tax records, most of which will never be required by the Australian Taxation Office, are immediately obvious.
As to the details of the fringe benefits tax on housing, which are on page 23, the booklet states:

A taxable housing fringe benefit arises where an employee (including members of the employee's family) is given by an employer the right to use a unit of accommodation as his or her usual place of residence.
That is not what Senator Haines said. It refers to the usual place of residence. It continues:
This includes the right to share occupation with others.
A unit of accommodation includes-
a house, flat or apartment;
accommodation in a hotel, motel, guesthouse, bunkhouse or other living quarters, in a ship or other vessel or floating structure, or a caravan or mobile home.

In Tasmania, as well as in the rest of this country, the motel and hotel business is an important part of our tourist industry. I shall read a telegram sent to me by the Executive Director of Flag Inns. It explains the motel and hotel situation pretty well. It starts off by saying:
The fringe benefits tax on employee accommodation and meals will increase the nation's hotel and motel tariffs and charges by an average of 9.6 per cent.

An average increase of nearly one-tenth will be required in hotel and motel charges. Honourable senators will hear me say further on that it will be worse than that in some cases. The telegram continues:
This imposition will force hotels and motels around Australia to generate this additional revenue in order just to pay the so-called in-house fringe benefits . . .

The average accommodation business demands 24-hour, 7-day a week on-site management. Essentially, this means personnel must reside on the premises in order to effectively provide the full services offered by the business and demanded by the consumer. Yet the Government wishes to put a further tax on this service.

As the tax is non-deductible, a measure which in itself runs counter to section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the industry will need to derive an additional $150 million in order to meet the tax.

Tariffs and charges will need to increase by 9.6% across the board to cover the costs. This, together with the increase of labour and all other costs of operations, will result in a massive inflationary increase in accommodation and hospitality costs of some 20% in the next twelve months. This will have horrendous consequences for the economy and for our competitiveness in the international marketplace.

I interpose that, just at a time when many people from the United States are beginning to come to this country instead of going to Europe, we are putting our charges up by about 10 per cent. The telegram goes on:
The tax is on labour costs and not on `tall poppy' fringe benefits, as was the initial proposition.

Following a 30% reduction to restaurant turnover as a result of the non-deductibility of entertainment costs, this legislation, if passed, will further reduce the labour workforce and send many businesses, which are only just surviving with the record highest real interest rates, to the wall.

Revised Treasury estimates that this tax will raise $570 million are grossly understated. In one instance, the tax on a 44-unit motel property in Western Australia is calculated to be $104,482, necessitating an intolerable increase of 62% in tariffs and charges. This estimate excludes cost of borrowing funds to pay the tax.

There are a couple of other paragraphs to that telegram which are in roughly the same vein. Of course, one does not have to be an Einstein to realise that what that gentleman says is correct. Hotel and motel managers need to be on the premises in order to cater for the requirements of people who want to use that accommodation. One would have to be crazy to think otherwise.

Some speakers from the Labor benches have said that the Fraser Government left anomalies in the taxation system. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Australian Democrats have used abuse to try to justify this legislation. Whenever we have pointed to the horrendous costs that these taxes will cause to businesses which employ so many people around the country we have been abused. I do not think that that is ever a good way of arguing, but it is one that we have seen a lot of recently. The Government has said that it is trying to make the tax equitable. I believe that that is just a smoke-screen to camouflage the terrible effects that this tax will have on so many small businesses and farms around the country. Perhaps big businesses will survive this socialist onslaught. My worry is that small businesses will find it all too time consu- ming, boring and dull and they will just give up altogether.

Earlier today Senator Cook said that we predicted that taxes on restaurants would create difficulty. Well, they have and many examples can be given. He also mentioned the housing industry. He said that we had claimed that some of the Government's measures would affect that industry. It may be that the high interest rates prevailing at the moment have had an effect too, but if one looks at the housing industry, one finds that it is not going very well. In fact, everything this Government touches starts going bad. Senator Cook would not answer the point about charities. I tried to get him to commit himself on that but he would not do so. Of course charities will be affected by this ill thought out tax scheme. This was mentioned ably by Senator Sir John Carrick a little while ago. Then Senator Cook said that New Zealand has a tax of this kind. To use New Zealand as an example to justify taxing employers in this way is not a very good idea. The New Zealand economy is a disaster; it has lost its triple A rating in world finance and most probably if it really wanted to it could obtain Third World status. Because of the New Zealand economy and as a result of our open door policy with that country, so many New Zealanders are coming here and it is costing this country more than $60m a year to keep their unemployed on the dole. We pay $60m a year to New Zealanders who have the highest unemployment rate of any sector in this country. I believe it is time that we had a very searching look at that. People in other countries think that we are crazy to support certain groups and allow certain things to happen as we do. I believe the community feels that as well. It is time we set about correcting those anomalies rather than trying to think up new taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Government in the Senate would no doubt be aware that the Australian Council of Trade Unions executive has indicated that it has rejected deferral of the promised tax cuts and further discounting of wages. Does the Minister agree that if the Government and the ACTU are unable to come to any agreement on tax cuts and on slowing down wage rises, the burden of economic policy aimed at getting Australia out of its current difficulties will have to be borne much more by cuts in government spending and higher interest rates?
—I am not an expert in these matters but I think that the answer to that question is yes.

—Can the Minister for Community Services explain to the Senate why the Melbourne Coonac Rehabilitation Centre is to be closed? What arrangements will be made to cater for its clients and staff? When will Coonac effectively close?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The provision of rehabilitation services in settings such as Coonac's is contrary to contemporary rehabilitation principles. The principles strongly support the concept of providing services in a way that causes the least restriction to individuals. Wherever possible we want to enable people to obtain those services in their local community. People with disabilities and their representatives accept this principle. The Commonwealth rehabilitation service developed in a vacuum after the Second World War. As a result, established services now are certainly out of keeping with that principle which I have just enunciated and are frequently well away from the people being treated. To give an example in Sydney-which has the best example-the Mount Wilga Rehabilitation Centre is on the far North Shore of Sydney. The other large centre is the Queen Elizabeth II Rehabilitation Centre at Camperdown. Both are well away from the centres of population. As a result people have to travel long distances to these centres. In the case of one centre in Australia, 25 per cent of the cost of rehabilitation goes on transporting people to and from the centre.

ANSWER.PARA: Studies have indicated that the greatest need for services in Melbourne is in the western and north-western suburbs, not in Toorak where Coonac is located. The closure of Coonac will free financial and staffing resources, resulting in the establishment of four regional office units in Melbourne. These types of units will provide very effective rehabilitation. More clients than before will be seen in the rehabilitation service. They are able to be treated more effectively. In addition, a specialist head injury unit will be established to continue the head injury program which is being conducted at Coonac at the moment. Those few clients who require intensive centre-based services will be offered treatment at the Glen Waverley Rehabilitation Centre. There are also alternative State and private facilities available in Melbourne. Most of the staff will be offered positions at the new rehabilitation units. Some may be offered positions at Glen Waverley. Where suitable positions cannot be provided every effort will be made in consultation with the unions to place staff elsewhere within the Department or within other Commonwealth departments. The closure will be phased. Clients and staff will be transferred to the new rehabilitation units as they are established from June this year. It is anticipated that the last rehabilitation unit will be established at about the end of 1986, making it possible, we hope, to close Coonac by that date. Coonac will be the first rehabilitation centre as such to be closed. We have closed residential centres throughout Australia in recent times, in keeping with demand and in keeping with modern practices, but I have no doubt that Coonac will not be the last centre to be closed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Was Australia part of the 17-nation war crimes tribunal which entrusted the United Nations with archive reports of 40,000 nazi war criminals? If so, will Australia give its assent to the requests of Israel and Austria for the release of these files? Will the Department of Foreign Affairs review these United Nations archives in view of recent media reports of the presence of nazi war criminals in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia was an original member of the 17-nation United Nations War Crimes Commission which was established on 20 October 1943 and which continued its work until its dissolution at the end of March 1984. The UNWCC's archives included periodical lists of about 37,000 war criminals, security suspects and witnesses, as well as other important files. The archives of the UNWCC were passed to the United Nations upon the Commission's dissolution. On 9 May 1986, the Secretary-General of the United Nations wrote to representatives of former members of the War Crimes Commission in New York, conveying a request from Israel that the files of the UNWCC should now be made public. The Secretary-General is thus consulting all the members of the now defunct Commission on the nature of his response to the Israeli request.

ANSWER.PARA: The Secretary-General has noted that, under the rules of access administered by the United Nations, restrictions are applied to documents `that refer to specified individuals charged or suspected of war crimes'. Access to these files is granted to governments which request them for the purpose of conducting prosecutions of war crimes. In these cases, the documents are provided on condition that they will be handled on the same basis of confidentiality as any other material being used in a criminal investigation. Over the years very few requests for documents have been made by governments. Recently, however, the UN handed 356 files to Israel at its request. The matter of Australia's response to the Secretary-General, which raises important issues, is under active study. We understand that no decision will be made by the Secretary-General until he has consulted all the former members of the Commission.

I just add, on behalf of Mr Hayden, that Senator Ray will appreciate that it is beyond the existing resources of the Department of Foreign Affairs to conduct a review of the Archives of the United Nations War Crimes Commission, but the Government could consider other courses of action in the light of its examination of the situation. I am advised that a member of the Australian Permanent Mission to the United Nations has discussed the subject with the United Nations Secretariat in a preliminary fashion. As I have said, further clarifications are required before it becomes clear what the future rules of access may be. The Government is aware of the urgency of the situation and it will be dealt with expeditiously.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs explain why the non-nuclear weapon states, that are signatories to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, including Australia, should continue to be part of this Treaty when the United States of America has unilaterally withdrawn from SALT II, a measure which is commonly recognised as the most effective nuclear arms control mechanism? Will the Australian Government take immediate steps to inform the United States of its concern at United States repudiation of SALT II? Will the Australian Government now consider withdrawing from the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and, if not, what other steps will it take?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I indicated what the Government's attitude was toward the issue of United States compliance with the SALT II Treaty which, of course, it never formally endorsed. The Australian Government attaches great importance to the existing regime of nuclear arms control, including SALT II, and for that reason we are concerned about the United States action. But to suggest, as Senator Sanders just has, that any concern one might reasonable have about the effective demise of SALT II should be responded to by a withdrawal from the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty is an illustration of folly that is extravagant even for the Australian Democrats. It is a classic example of throwing out the baby with what is left of the bath water.
—Are you going to protest?

—I indicated yesterday what the Government's position will be in relation to SALT II. The nature of the Australian Government's response-a constructive response, it will be hoped-is being very actively considered by the Government at the moment. But the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty has been perhaps the only but certainly the most conspicuously successful of the arms control agreements that have been entered into over the years, in that it has succeeded, much against many people's expectations, in controlling the proliferation of nuclear weapons by virtue of the three-way agreement that was entered into by the nuclear weapon states not to make that technology available to non-weapon states, by the agreement of non-weapon states not to seek to acquire arms technology and by the agreement of all the participants, as we have said often enough, to exchange freely material and technology relating to the peaceful uses of nuclear power. That has been a conspicuously successful arrangement and it has succeeded, by force perhaps of moral example, even if not legal effect, in stopping the proliferation of nuclear weapons even among those states which are not signatory to it.

ANSWER.PARA: The review conference that took place last year was another demonstration of the inherent power of that Treaty to continue to command the active assent and involvement of a great many nations around the world. To seek now, out of some feeble-minded gesture of emotional protest, to withdraw from that Treaty or to encourage others to do so I think is a demonstration of the extreme irresponsibility that unfortunately we have come to expect from so many who espouse the cause of nuclear disarmament with alleged sincerity in this Parliament.

I am advised that information given to the Australian Customs Service about individual importations into Australia is given and held in confidence, and confidential information cannot be disclosed. In the case of asbestos imports, it would be possible to make information available upon request to a Commonwealth agency such as the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission or the Department of Health if the information was to be used by that agency for the purpose of performing its function. That may not be an adequate answer to the question which Senator Bolkus has put to me but I will undertake to see what further information I can obtain, and give it to him as early as possible.

—My question is also addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In Senator Richardson's interview on AM this morning he characterised the Government as one big Irish family. Can the Leader of the Government in the Senate assure the Senate that the Government's relationships do not compare closely with a Sicilian family and that after yesterday's disastrous economic news Mr Keating's feet are only encased in clay rather than cement? In view of the Treasurer's critical comments last night about the Prime Minister's staff and Mr Hawke's godfatherly defence of his minders on Sydney radio today, can the Minister advise the Senate whether there will be any upcoming political bereavements within the family and, if so, will they emerge in keeping with the Irish or the Sicilian tradition?
—You should go back on the radio.

—I really cannot contribute much to this. Senator Walsh has suggested that Senator Baume should go back on radio. I do not know what program anyone would have him on. Perhaps he should do that. Irish or Sicilian, the family looks after its own here and one of the first things we will do is fix Senator Michael Baume right up.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction read an article in the Australian Financial Review of 23 May 1986 entitled `Department would be abolished'? That article on the Opposition's housing policy states that the Opposition wants to renegotiate the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement to achieve, firstly, elimination of tied grants for public housing; secondly, incorporation of funds from the Government's very successful first home owners scheme; and, thirdly, inclusion of provisions to sell off public housing as well as the introduction of greater needs based assessments for access to public housing. Does the Minister believe that such measures proposed by the Opposition simply show callous disregard for people who need public housing, and are further evidence of the Opposition's failure to come to grips with the necessity of providing public housing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The article discussing the housing policy of the Liberal Party of Australia has been drawn to my attention, and I do agree with Senator Foreman that it shows callous disregard for low income families who are in need of public housing. In the section on public housing it is the case that the Opposition shows a clear ignorance of housing problems and the overall housing situation. The Opposition, by proposing to eliminate tied grants, seems not to be aware of the fact that these grants currently go to rental housing for Aboriginals, for crisis accommodation such as women's and youth refuges, for housing provided by local government and community groups, for age pensioners and for persons facing short term mortgage and rent problems. The result of the intention of the Liberals to abolish the tied grants would be the abolition of housing assistance for all of those needy groups. The whole reason for tied grants is to ensure those most needy get priority help. About $140m in this financial year is being devoted to tied grants for the needy, and the Opposition would stop these grants.

ANSWER.PARA: The Liberals would also incorporate the first home owners scheme in public housing funds for the States, which would effectively abolish the scheme and would force the States to decide to help either first home buyers or those who need public housing, whereas, of course, both groups are helped under our present policies. Their proposal to enable the sale of public housing shows ignorance because such sales can happen already under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement with conditions that ensure that, if a dwelling is sold, it is able to be replaced with the proceeds from the sale. Otherwise, of course, public rental stock would be reduced. Any policy that sold off public housing stock without such restrictions would seriously harm the chances of those in need getting help.

The policy also states that it would make public housing more needs based but, of course, our public housing policies are already focused on those in the community most in need. About 70 per cent of public tenants are on Commonwealth pensions and benefits, and the remaining 30 per cent are on very low incomes. Liberal policy can only mean that it will force people out of public housing, for example, if they get a job. Of course, the policy contains no indication of funding. Based on the Liberals' record in housing we can only guess what they would do. Their record in public housing was appalling. By 1980-81 the Liberals had cut public housing funding to $264m-only 40 per cent of funding during the last year of the Whitlam Government. In the first year of the Hawke Government we increased public housing by 40 per cent, and there have been significant increases since. I think Australians should be in no doubt that if policies such as this had any chance of being implemented, the impact and public housing and on the people most in need would be catastrophic.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Minister representing the Minister for Defence could tear himself away from the racing pages, perhaps--
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to ask her question.

—Could the Minister representing the Minister for Defence advise the Senate as to what actual progress has been made towards the speedy implementation of the recommendations of the Hamilton report into living conditions for service families?
—Not much progress was ever made when your husband was involved in it.
—Order!

—I endorse Senator Grimes's contribution. I have absolutely no idea what has happened to the Hamilton report, about which I have never heard. If the honourable senator will put the question on notice I am sure she will get an answer in due course.

—Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of a study recently published in the New England Journal of Medicine which claims to be the first study which shows a cause and effect relationship between drafted military servicemen in Vietnam and a high risk of suicide? Does the Minister subscribe to the basic conclusion of the study that `the casualties of forced military service may not be limited to those that are counted on the battlefield'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the report that has been published in the New England Journal of Medicine; the inquiry was directed by a Dr Norman Hearst of the University of California, San Francisco. That report suggests that the conscripted Vietnam veterans are nearly twice as likely to commit suicide as are men in the same age group who did not serve in a war. Dr Hearst believes that the study demonstrates that the experience of being drafted during the Vietnam era has a profound long term effect upon those conscripted. Earlier studies conducted by other eminent persons has found high levels of depression, drug abuse, marital problems, criminal charges and other difficulties among veterans. But that report tended to be deprecated on the basis of its limited survey. Critics had speculated that the draftees had trouble because they were more likely to be poorer or less educated than those who avoided the draft and not because of the lingering effects of military service.

ANSWER.PARA: The latest study is important because it is based on a review of deaths of 14,145 men born in the United States between 1950 and 1952 and those who died in 1974 to 1983. That survey showed that the likelihood of suicide was 85 per cent higher among those who were drafted to serve in Vietnam and it also showed that the higher risk-53 per cent of fatal car accidents-dropped to normal after the first few years. Nevertheless, the higher suicide rate was maintained. This study specifically removes the bias sample which, it had been suggested, gave rise to incorrect conclusions previously. The reasons suggested by Dr Hearst included physical handicaps-one does not need to conjure up a picture of the use of land mines and so on that would create that sort of problem-social and economic problems after returning to civilian life; susceptibility to and recurring mental illnesses; and familiarity with fire-arms. The conclusions in the study suggest that before sending young men to war those who make the decision should weigh up all the costs and the consequences and remind themselves that the casualties are not necessarily just those that take place on the battlefield.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer him to the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures which indicate that investment in manufacturing plant and equipment has fallen sharply in the last quarter. I ask: How long are the expected lead times between new investment in manufacturing plant and equipment and the reflection of this investment in increased exports or import replacement? Is not such investment vital for economic recovery? What explanations does the Government have for the reluctance of manufacturing industry to invest in new plant and equipment, in view of the opportunities opened up by the devalued dollar? Is not new investment dependent on a belief by business that its competitive position will not be ruined by new taxes, high interest rates, increased labour costs and overheads and, as far as exports are concerned, reliable port handling? What is the Government doing to restore business confidence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since this Government came to office the profit share, apart from increasing in percentage terms, has increased by between $6 billion and $7 billion. We have the lowest real unit labour costs and the lowest level of industrial disputes since the late 1960s, and real award wages have fallen over a period of three successive years during which economic growth has been at very high levels by Australian standards. I do not know what more a government can be expected to do for business than that. Certainly, it is more than any government within memory has done for business in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Having put those facts on the record, I must say that the figures on private investment in plant and equipment are disappointing. I do not know the degree to which they may subsequently be revised any more than I can say in any precise way what the lead time ought to be between the growth of the gross domestic product and the recovery of private investment in plant and equipment. As to the reference to new taxes, the fundamental inability of members of the Liberal Party and tory politicians in general to follow a logical train of thought has often astounded me. They simultaneously tell us now that the nation's economy is collapsing, decaying, et cetera; and that the answer to all this is to preserve the free lunch, the fringe benefits tax, the absence of a capital gains tax and all the things which have existed during the period in which, they say, the economy has decayed to a point where it is disintegrating.

Their formula for repairing the situation which they say has developed is to keep all the policies under which it developed. Of course, without any doubt, one of the reasons that the Australian economy has performed very poorly over several decades, compared to those countries with which we could reasonably compare ourselves, is the widespread compradore ethos of Australian capitalism manifested in a passionate commitment to the perpetuation of things such as the free lunch, the fringe benefit and the gathering of income from untaxed capital gains instead of through investment and activity in productive endeavour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. As this Government's record of maintaining high rates of investment and growth in the Australian airline industry, both domestically and internationally, is well known, and given that there is some uncertainty on what direction interest rates will take, will the Minister inform the Senate of the future outlook for the industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will not need to be reminded of the state of our airline industry, both domestic and overseas, when this Government came to office. It was in a very depressed state. Certainly it was my recollection that Qantas Airways Ltd was losing money, and I think the same could be said of both the government and privately-owned airlines. That is not the position today. There has been a remarkable turnaround in the airline industry.

ANSWER.PARA: I thank the honourable senator for his question. I appreciate that it probably arises out of his membership and leadership of the aviation sub-committee of the Parliamentary Labor Party. The Government's record in this area of stimulating the economy and the flow-on effects in the airline industry is well known. As a current indicator, for example, international passenger activity has increased by 8 per cent in the December quarter and, overall, by 8.5 per cent during 1985. Annual inward traffic increased by 9.1 per cent and outward traffic by 7.8 per cent. That is in stark contrast to the conditions that existed in 1982-83. The index of published schedule economy fares rose by 3.3 per cent in real terms and the index of minimum fares rose by 1.8 per cent.

The recent reduction in the import parity price of local oil comes as a welcome relief to the airline industry. However, because interest rates remain high and there has been a steady decline in exchange rates, both these impact on operating costs and the capacity to maintain growth at appropriate yield. Nevertheless, there has been an increase, as Senator Sibraa suggested, in investments in these areas. That is reflected in the aggregate movements into and out of Australia of about 6 to 7 per cent during the current year of 1986.

It is worth recalling that there has been a substantial increase in air freight during the last period. A considerable increase has taken place-a 12 per cent growth last year in international freight charters-and a review of the international air freight policy last year has led to an increase in activity of 20 per cent in scheduled freight services. The outlook is for further growth in imports and moderate growth in exports. That indicates that the Government's economic policies are being reflected in the airline industry, a very important industry from the point of view of moving both freight and passenger traffic.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to today's Press coverage of the South Australian Premier's comments yesterday at a meeting of Labor Premiers, which Mr Wran refused to attend, in which Mr Bannon attacked `political patronage and pork-barrelling' and the potential damage to Australia's submarine project. Firstly, since the South Australian Premier's confident prediction and advertisements of last year that South Australia was up and running on the submarine project, what circumstances have changed to give occasion to this blunt outburst by Mr Bannon? Secondly, can the Leader of the Government assure the Senate that the substantial submarine project is not to be the subject of a special deal engineered by the New South Wales Premier, regarded by some as one of the Prime Minister's little mates?

—I did not see what Premier Bannon said. I hear from all the Premiers on this issue. They all seem very anxious, and I guess they will be like that until the submarine contract is ultimately let. There is no reason for any heightened level of anxiety among Premiers on the basis of the sort of speculation advanced in Senator Vanstone's question-there is no reason for that at all.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been directed to the latest report of the Foreign Investment Review Board published this week? If so, can the Minister indicate any new and significant investment trends reported by the FIRB? Do any of the trends give the Government cause for concern?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of some of the information in the most recent report of the Foreign Investment Review Board. Before getting to that matter, I am also aware of concerns expressed by a prominent Queensland businessman, Sir Roderick Proctor, on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio a couple of weeks ago. I believe that Sir Roderick is still a director of the National Party in Queensland and a close associate of the Premier.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The question clearly has nothing to do with the Minister's answer. The question has nothing to do with Sir Roderick Proctor, or anyone else, and I ask you to rule that the Minister is out of order.
—There is no point of order.
—I can understand why Senator Boswell does not want Sir Roderick Proctor's remarks to be rebroadcast because he said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Queensland economy is not in good shape and in some respects at the moment we do not compare well with some of the other States, which just happen to have Labor State governments. The Queensland economy is performing at a level below that of Victoria and New South Wales.

Shifting now to the international scene and to the Foreign Investment Review Board report, to which Senator Maguire referred and which is the 1984-85 report, it contains some interesting figures for new investment approved for Australia. This is investment in the economic sense-that is, investment in new projects and not changes of ownership of existing projects or assets. The figures show a slight increase nationally between 1983-84 and 1984-85 of about $20m in round figures. However, the interesting statistic is Queensland's share of that total figure as follows: In 1983-84 Queensland had approved foreign investment of $499m, and in 1984-85 that had fallen to $207m of that portion of total new foreign investment that can be identified with one State. As an explanation of what might appear to be a discrepancy in the figure I am about to quote and the one I have already quoted, I point out that it is not always possible to apportion new foreign investment to a particular State. On the same basis, Queensland's share of foreign investment has been effectively halved; that is, down from 26.6 per cent in 1983-84 to 13.7 per cent in 1984-85. That figure of 13.7 per cent is, of course, significantly lower than Queensland's share of the population, which stands at 16 per cent. For a considerable time Queensland-because of the mineral resources in that State and the propensity of mineral resource development to be associated with the investment of new foreign capital-attracted a larger than proportional share of foreign investment. Indeed, that fact caused the Premier, along with conservative politicians in general, to boast and pride themselves on their ability to attract foreign investment. The latest figures show that the international business community lacks confidence in the Queensland economy and the Bjelke-Petersen Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education. Has consideration been given to the transfer of the Australian Capital Territory Apprenticeship Board from the Minister's Department to the Department of Territories? If it has, can she outline the reason for that action being considered? Does this also mean that the colleges of technical and further education in the Australian Capital Territory will also be transferred from her Department to the Department of Territories?

—Consideration is being given to the transfer of the Apprenticeship Board to the Department of Territories. Consideration is not being given to the transfer of the TAFE colleges to the Department of Territories. We consider it appropriate to keep the TAFE colleges as part of the tertiary sector, and therefore administered by the Commonwealth Department of Education, although we may well find a new structure of administration when we finish reviewing higher education and tertiary education in the Australian Capital Territory. In the case of the Apprenticeship Board, a strong argument has been put that it is very much a local matter of supervising local apprentices, that the Board comprises trades people working in the local industry and it is more appropriately dealt with at a local level. The matter has not yet been finished, but that is the direction in which it is heading.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of the Minister's answer, while appreciating the local nature of the Board, in view of its close relationship with the TAFE colleges and the significant role they play together, is it not very significant that that relationship should be taken into account and the Board be kept under the same department as the colleges?
—All of the relevant aspects are being considered and I will take Senator Reid's views into account.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is the Government aware of the fact that, despite the re-entry of nuclear-powered warships into Australian ports in 1976, there are no adequate port safety plans to deal with a nuclear reactor accident in Western Australia-and probably the same applies in other States as well? Is the Government aware that the November 1984 draft of the port safety scheme-the most recent document, which is not available to the public-makes no mention of decontamination procedures, and that three significant areas dealing with evacuation plans, the issuing of potassium iodate tablets and public information plans are still to be prepared? Does not the Government, which invites or allows nuclear-powered warships into Australian ports, have a duty to ensure that the State's port safety plans are completed and operative after a 10-year period? Does the Government not also have a responsibility to the public to ensure that citizens are informed about emergency procedures in the case of an accident? Finally, will any of the warships being invited to join the Royal Australian Navy's 75th anniversary celebrations be nuclear-powered?

—Port safety plans are the responsibility of the relevant State or Territory governments. Public release of those plans is likewise a matter for State and Territory governments. The Commonwealth Government, for its part, supports and encourages these governments in moves to release information about their emergency planning. Because Senator Vallentine referred to a Western Australian document, the Government is not in a position at this stage to comment on the status of the reported November 1984 draft of the port safety scheme which she appears to have obtained; nor to comment in detail on the allegations she made about it. As to the last part of the question, no nuclear-powered warship visits are planned for the RAN's 75th anniversary review in Sydney in October 1986.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN COUNCIL OF TRADE UNIONS: STOPPAGE

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Leader of the Government in the Senate seen a report showing that the Australian Council of Trade Unions regarded its recent national day of protest as a great success? Has the Minister also seen reports that the effects of that stoppage included, firstly, a loss of domestic production totalling millions of dollars and, secondly, a loss of millions of dollars in export earnings at a time when Australia has a record trade deficit? Did it further prejudice Australia's reputation as a reliable and prompt supplier of such exports? Does he not agree that the ACTU support for the stoppage raises doubts as to the economic responsibility of the ACTU, particularly in light of the fact that it will have ample opportunity to air its views at the forthcoming meeting of the Advisory Committee on Prices and Incomes?

—I guess the stoppage took place because of the delay in the hearing of the national wage case. That was the stated reason. The national wage case, of course, is dealing with the consumer price index figures for the December quarter last year. There have been considerable delays in passing on the wage increase following the CPI increase in any particular quarter. The fact is that this year there will have been one wage increase in Australia of the order of 3.7 per cent.
—When we can't afford it.

—Whether or not we can afford it is another argument. Having said that, I do not think the ACTU's endorsing or invoking of the so-called national stoppage yesterday was a good idea. I think it was not a very smart idea at all. I hope that the ACTU can be encouraged to persuade its constituents to be patient a little longer in respect of the current national wage case because I think that in the current economic climate it is very important that it does so. However, let me repeat that there have been enormous changes in attitudes to these questions in the trade union movement. Those changes should be encouraged rather than any slight breakdown in the process of change being seized on as some useful political weapon in the Senate or something of that kind.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer concerned about continuing calls to evade the payment of Federal Government taxes? Can the Minister explain why so many of these calls emanate from his home town in Perth?
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. That question is out of order because it relates to a matter before the Senate.
—On the point of order: My question refers to the payment of Federal Government taxes as a generality. I do not think it is out of order.

—Order! I will allow the first part of the question, but the second part of the question is very vague and far removed from the Minister's immediate responsibility to this House. I ask the Minister, in answering, to remember that there is legislation before this chamber which will be debated immediately after Question Time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr President. Obviously this question is more specific than the question of any particular Bill levying a tax, because it entails calls by people in responsible positions to break the law of the land. There was a most unfortunate rash of that sort of irresponsible activity one week, when the ratbag Right, personified by people such as Ian McLachlan, the Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia and, unfortunately, a recent addition to the ratbag Right, Mr Bob Ansett, were calling for people to break the law of the land and refuse to pay taxes which would be levied by the Parliament according to constitutional processes. While I am on this subject, I think I ought to clear up a matter which was raised by Senator Chaney in Question Time last Wednesday, when he took a point of order and said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . Mr Hassell made it quite clear that he is not advocating breaches of the law.
It is true that in a statement reported in last Tuesday's West Australian Mr Hassell backed away from his earlier call. However, for the record, I quote from the West Australian of Monday, 26 May:
The Leader of the West Australian Opposition, Mr Hassell, said that four immediate, practical steps could be taken by West Australian business representatives.
The article gives four points, the second of which is to refuse to pay the tax. Later in the article Mr Hassell is quoted directly as saying:
In Western Australia I commit the Liberal Party to lead the tax revolt.

That is to defy the law of the land, to repudiate the rule of law. It is true-I again say to Senator Chaney's credit-that on Monday of this week he was quoted as unequivocally rejecting that call and the call from other members of the ratbag Right to whom I have referred. It is to his credit that he had the courage to stand out, even in the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party, and to say that those sorts of calls copied the tactics of the most lawless elements of the trade union movement as, I suppose, personified by the Builders Labourers Federation in the south-eastern States. I agree entirely with the honourable senator in that assessment and I admire him for having the courage and the decency to say so. But the fact remains that the State Liberal Party Leader, with the implicit support of the temporarily ruling clique of the Liberal Party in Western Australia, at Mr Hassell's--

TALK.START.PARA: —That Crichton-Browne will be up to his ears in that.
—Yes, Senator Crichton-Browne, Mr Payne, Mr Hassell and the rest of that gang. Mr Hassell said that the business community should refuse to pay the tax and said:

ANSWER.PARA: In Western Australia I commit the Liberal Party to lead the tax revolt.

Certainly by Tuesday he had backed away from that. But the significant point is that he showed his mind before he had a chance to curb his tongue. His mind is a lawless mind. To repudiate the law of the land, repudiate the rule of law generally, is to behave as one would expect a member of the ratbag Right to behave.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to an article in today's Age that indicated that the Commissioner of Taxation is intending to raise 10,000 assessments against taxpayers involved with so-called bottom of the harbour tax avoidance schemes? Can the Minister confirm that report? If so, can the Minister advise on what basis such assessments will be raised? Are these assessments likely to be based on the same grounds as was the Hawke Labor Government's unreasonable legislation which has already been twice rejected by the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not looked at the Age today and I have not seen that report, but I accept Senator Messner's statement that what he claims to have been reported was reported. I am very grateful to Senator Messner for raising this question because it is an opportune time to have a quick look back at the bottom of the harbour legislation and the claims that were made about it at the time. I remember quite clearly that there were a number of hysterically exaggerated claims from assorted members of the then Government parties-the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia-asserting that these bottom of the harbour operators did not have the money to pay the tax anyway. Those were the members of the Liberal Party who were opposing their own Government's legislation. They said that the bottom of the harbour operators did not have the money to pay the tax anyway because they had all invested it back in their businesses to generate employment for the workers and that really they were philanthropists. They said that they were not frauds, cheats and thieves at all but philanthropists who had just constructively used this money they had evaded in taxation by putting it back into the business for productive investment to provide jobs for the workers and goods and services for the community. It was further asserted that, if those people were forced to pay the tax that they ought to have paid years before, the businesses would be bankrupted and would have to close down, unemployment would explode and chaos would hit the land.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, what actually happened was that the very time that the collection of that tax in any volume commenced-that is, in the autumn and winter of 1983-just happened to be the time that the economy started pulling out of recession and employment was growing, as it has continued to grow at a very high rate right up to the most recent employment figures available. The relevance of that little bit of history, of course, is that exactly the same people use exactly the same sorts of false arguments in defence of tax evaders every time a taxation Bill is introduced. They have been proved wrong on every occasion. I do not know the grounds on which the Commissioner has issued these assessments but I will ask the Treasurer whether he can supply the information.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Has he seen a report in yesterday's Brisbane Courier-Mail in which a Gold Coast based company was alleged to have used a system of fines to discipline employees who committed offences such as being late for meetings, saying anything negative and fraternising with employees of the opposite sex? Can the Minister say whether abuses of power such as this would be more prevalent under the coalition's industrial relations policy as it includes a system of individual agreements which would be virtually impossible to police?

—My attention has been drawn to that report but I am not in a position to say whether it is accurate. It is conceivable that the types of practices referred to in the report could have occurred. It is a matter of common sense that, if there is a multiplicity of possibly thousands of individual agreements, it is more likely that malpractices of that nature will occur. Senator Black mentioned the difficulty of policing, say, several thousand individual agreements; and that is self-evident. The reality is that the industrial relations policy of the Liberal Party of Australia will not be implemented because the Liberal Party will not be in government to implement it-or at least, the Howard-led Liberal Party will not be in government to implement it. That is a statement of reality which an increasing number of people in the Liberal Party realise to be true. In the hypothetical case of such a policy being implemented, I find it somewhat ironical that the party that has said it is for small government, a small bureaucracy, low government expenditure and all that sort of thing, could contemplate a policy which to police effectively would require, as Senator Black suggests, the commitment of enormous resources. I will see whether I can get any further information about whether the allegations of malpractice, as reported, are correct.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer why the Commissioner of Taxation is issuing more than one assessment in respect of the same items of income? Does not this practice result in one assessment being inconsistent with the other and also in double taxation?

—I was not aware of that fact, if indeed it is a fact. If the Commissioner is issuing more than one assessment for the same income, I cannot imagine why he is doing so, unless he has decided to send two assessments to members of the former Liberal Party Finance Committee on the ground that he might be able to get them to pay some tax now; they did not pay any in the past because most of them were involved in bottom of the harbour operations. I will inquire about that matter.

—My question is to the Minister for Community Services. What progress has been achieved in the development of a procedure to deal with complaints from patients and residents in nursing homes and hostels and clients of other Federal Government funded or subsidised services which are conducted by non-governmental organisations or private enterprise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Giles well knows, the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes of which she was chairperson recommended the establishment of a mechanism for complaints and disputes for clients of government establishments or establishments funded by the Government, such as nursing homes, hostels, refuges, et cetera. In the nursing homes and hostels review we pointed out that the Attorney-General and I have established a task force to examine the various options which might be available to the Commonwealth in this area. The task force has submitted an interim report and it is preparing a final report which will cover the issue of a special and particular complaints body. The interim report covers all Commonwealth subsidised programs in the Department of Community Services and not just nursing homes. It points out the need for co-operation in this area between the Commonwealth and the States as well as between the service providers and the users. It also emphasises that an effective mechanism, apart from having a special complaints body, will involve the development of measures such as increased information for prospective residents, minimum standards of care, greater user participation and greater knowledge generally by the people in those residences and their relatives. The task force considered that the potential for major disputes could be lessened by the development of such measures and also recognised that, while implementing all the necessary changes will be a long process, there is no simple solution. Nevertheless, a number of significant advances have been made and a variety of measures have already been implemented in the Department of Community Services.

ANSWER.PARA: We established an Office for the Aged and an Office of Disability, and they have been consulting consumer groups throughout the country. The Department has developed a draft discussion document on the quality of care in nursing homes. The first part includes a section on residents' rights relating to aspects such as self-determination, religious and ethnic observances, risk taking, financial affairs and such matters. The section also urges nursing homes to establish residents' committees so that residents can plan and manage some aspects of their care and give advice on others. The manual also outlines minimum standards and there has been considerable development in this area with the co-operation of operators as well as users. The most important criterion in the development of a complaints mechanism such as this is that it does not become overbureaucratic and an easy source of trouble-making by people who want to make vexatious complaints. It also should recognise that many of the differences can be resolved by people discussing them and gaining greater knowledge of each other's problems. The New South Wales Government has started developing a complaints mechanism of this type. We want to ensure that we are not just duplicating what that State or other States will do. I expect that in the next few months we will be much further down the track and that I will then be able to give the Senate and the Parliament a fuller report on the advances we have made.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-During Question Time Senator Walsh claimed that, by implicit support, I had supported calls by others to break a law which does not exist. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't deny you said it.

—I am enjoined by way of an interjection not to deny that I advocated the breaking of a law, section 55b of the Western Australian Police Act, which holds as law that, if three people gather together in a public place without police permission and discuss matters of public importance, they do so illegally and can be arrested and gaoled because of it. —Thank you, Mr President. And advocating--

—Thank you, Mr President; I am doing that. I do not deny in the sense of the accusation made that I advocated breaking that law, and I stand by that. However, I have not been hypocritical, pretending that I do not do that, whereas Mr Hassell pretends to uphold the rule of law and now denies it.
