SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I present the 251st report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts entitled `Advance to the Minister for Finance (1982-83)-Response' which contains the Department of Finance minute on the Committee's 228th report.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-Report 251 of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts considers the Department of Finance minute relating to the Committee's 228th report on the Advance to the Minister for Finance 1982-83. The Advance to the Minister for Finance is a provision authorised by the annual Appropriation Acts and made available to the Minister. In 1982-83 amounts of $125m, $100m and $50m respectively were provided for this purpose in Appropriation Acts Nos 1, 2 and 3. As a general principle, the only amounts which should remain a charge to the appropriations for the Advance to the Minister for Finance at the end of the financial year are urgent and unforeseen expenditures which arise between the time of preparation of the additional Appropriation Bills and the close of the financial year. In its examination, the Committee seeks to ascertain whether or not expenditure from the Advance conforms to this general principle.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee received statements relating to 111 items of expenditure. Supplementary material was obtained concerning 10 items. Three items were selected for public inquiry:
Department of Aviation-office requisites and equipment;
Department of Defence-pay and allowances for the Army Reserve and cadets; and
Department of Transport-fuel, light and power.

As a result of its public inquiry into the management and control by the Department of Defence of payments to the Citizen Military Forces, Regular Army Emergency Reserve and Officers of Cadets of the Australian Cadet Corps, the Committee found some disturbing deficiencies. Overuse of the training day allocation arose because responsible officers were not able to line up actual training days worked and payments made or due with the overall planned number of training days per head. The control problems which permitted the excessive use of training days arose from, and were aggravated by, the lack of adequate and timely information on expenditure trends. The recently computerised pay system facilitated prompt payments of amounts due, resulting in a faster than expected rate of payment, but did not provide management with information for estimating purposes. The Committee notes that since its inquiry a number of actions have been taken to improve management and control, and that the item continues to receive close scrutiny. I recommend the report to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Land Acqusition in New South Wales by the Army

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence I present the first report on the acquisition of land by the Army in New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence has been inquiring into a proposal by the Department of Defence to acquire a large manoeuvre and live-firing area of approximately one million hectares at Cobar in western New South Wales and a site of some 73,000 hectares for a co-located infantry and artillery schools complex. The Committee's terms of reference also required it to consider the process of acquisition of land by the Commonwealth. The Committee has deferred consideration of that part of the reference until the proposed amendments to the Commonwealth Land Acquisition Act 1955 are available for public scrutiny. The first report of the Committee concentrates on the proposed manoeuvre area at Cobar. The schools proposal, which was deferred in April 1986, is discussed briefly in the report. The Committee's principal recommendations are:
That no further consideration be given to the Cobar proposal as a site for a manoeuvre area;
That no change be made to the existing location of the Infantry Centre at Singleton, New South Wales;
That the School of Artillery remain at North Head in the medium term; and
That the Army's user requirement for the School of Artillery be revised extensively before any future proposal for relocation is considered.

I would like to mention the enormous interest shown in the inquiry by people in areas likely to be affected by the possible acquisition of land for the Army. On the very day the terms of reference were announced, two lobby groups from countryside New South Wales were in King's Hall wanting to see me and other Committee members. In the weeks that followed, the Committee received many detailed submissions from different individuals and directly interested groups. Clearly, a lot of research and thought went into these submissions. This should not be surprising. People in these areas had lived in a condition of uncertainty since the possible acquisition of land was mooted in 1982 by the then Minister for Defence.

Concerns were different in different areas. People in the town of Singleton were obviously concerned that a relocation of the Army training area would have a negative impact on their economy. Landowners in mooted areas were worried about possible negative effects on their livelihood. Take, for instance, the case of a farmer with two properties, one inside the proposed area and one outside. The viability of his farm was in question if he was to loose access to one of the properties. A whole variety of similar problems were presented to the Committee.

I should also point out that people who were opposed to the land acquisition made it quite clear that they would willingly make the necessary sacrifices in a time of emergency. But in present peacetime circumstances, they did not appreciate the long-standing uncertainties they were faced with and did have doubts about the strategic value of acquiring land in that part of Australia. I believe that the people most likely to be affected by the possible acquisition do feel that they have been given every opportunity to have their views heard.

I would like to compliment these people for the dedicated and considerate way in which they have presented their views to the Committee, and I would especially like to compliment the staff of the Committee which had the onerous task of working through the large amount of material that was put before the Committee. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Clerk has just said, we are discussing the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 and associated fringe benefits tax Bills. I was speaking on this matter just before lunch.
—Are you going to incite people to break the law?

—I pointed out at that time that only academics or unionists such as Senator Cook, the union urger who is interjecting at the moment, would agree to this kind of tax being imposed. I believe that gradually the effect of this tax is sinking into the community. The cost of it is becoming visible because the Australian Taxation Office has been holding some seminars to try to explain this very complicated piece of legislation to those people who are interested in it and whom it will affect. In today's Mercury was a letter from a Mr J. T. Piper, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: Having attended a seminar on the proposed fringe benefits tax, I have become aware of the cost implications of this tax on my company, as well as the inflationary effect on Australia's economy as a whole. This comes at a time when the economy needs positive support, not hindrance, and I therefore feel such legislation should not be passed by the Federal Parliament.

That was in today's Mercury and it is an indication, I think, that people are starting to recognise that this is not something that applies just to tall poppies-it is going to apply a lot of pressure to small businesses within Australia. The net gain of this tax has been calculated to be very small, yet the cost of operating it is quite horrendous. I believe it will have a disastrous impact on the cost of operating small businesses, so it is obviously a tax on employment.

I mentioned before lunch that the Taxation Office had brought out a 56-page booklet which it sent to different businesses around the country to give them some indication of how to manage their affairs to obey this tax. It had many errors in it. It will be out of date if this Parliament makes any alterations to the tax Bills that are before us. It was put out without this Parliament having approved the legislation, which is something that I think should never happen. I do not think people in government departments can presume ever that legislation which hits this place will go through it unchanged. I mentioned also the cost of this taxation to the tourism industry via the expenses that will be applied to hotel and motel operators. I read from a telegram I had received from one of the motel associations which had anticipated that motels would have to put up their tariffs by just under 10 per cent to compensate for the requirements of this legislation.

We were told earlier by one of the Australian Labor Party senators that New Zealand had used this method of raising money. I pointed out that New Zealand has not a very good economy to watch because it has lost its triple A rating within the international financial markets. A lot of people are leaving New Zealand to come to this country. The fact that so many people are coming here and going on the dole is costing this country some $60m a year. That is why I find it quite amazing to use New Zealand as an example. In today's Sydney Morning Herald there was an article which was headed: `Kiwis led the way with tax, but many say it has failed'. I believe it is going to fail in this country. That article stated:

The New Zealand Government introduced a tax on fringe benefits on April 1, 1985. It was aimed mainly at those with company cars and cheap finance, although a long list of other `extras' were included . . .
The tax was expected to collect about $A154m within nine months but in fact it took just over half of that.

The Inland Revenue Department said only 8 per cent of the country's estimated 140,000 employers had been found liable for the tax while the other 92 per cent maintained that their employees did not receive benefits covered by the Government's definition of a perk.
Critics of the scheme were quick to use these statistics to brand the tax as a flop. `It was ill-conceived and badly instituted'--
one gentleman from a group of accountants said--
`By being too wide-ranging it became unenforceable and invited thousands of small businessmen to hold back and to break the law.'

I shall speak about this matter of breaking the law in a moment, as it is something that I do not agree with. Today I received a letter about this tax from a group that has recognised just what an effect it is going to have on them. The letter, dated 29 May, which I opened just a few minutes ago, comes from the Australian Parents Council Incorporated. I would like to read some of that letter to the Senate because I think it is of some interest. Under the heading `Fringe benefits tax', it states:

While supporting the principle that the burden of taxation should be equitably borne by the community, the Australian Parents Council believes that the fringe benefits tax is unnecessarily harsh and burdensome on non-government school communities.
I see Senator Teague nodding-he would agree with that entirely. He has taken a great interest in education.

TALK.START.PARA: —I spoke with them on Monday in Sydney and I believe that we should amend the Bill.

—I believe that the Bill should be amended, and Senator Teague says that because of this implication he believes that the Bill should be amended, and in fact that is what is asked for at the end of the letter. The letter goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The community recognises the special services rendered by non-government schools to Australian children and their families. The community also recognises that these non-profit educational institutions spend all their scarce resources on the education of children. To assist them to do so the Commonwealth Government exempts them from income tax and sales tax on purchases. Logically and in justice, the Commonwealth should exempt them from the operation of the fringe benefits tax. To subject non-government schools to the fringe benefits tax would impose on them a continual and growing administrative burden of record-keeping and documentation as well as subjecting them to complex and detailed self-assessment procedures. It seems that school authorities-
this points to the craziness of some of this legislation-

will have to keep records of suppers, lunches and dinners served at a range of routine school activities which their employees, the teachers, attend. Tax will have to be paid by the school on this assumed consumption of food although the teachers' attendance is required at these functions as part of their normal duties.

That is crazy. Who is going to work out what the value of these meals is? Further, with self-assessment, if an error is made, we do not really know how far back the Taxation Office will go. One might make an error and the Taxation Office will go back through the school's assessment for four or five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Democrats are going to support this nonsense, too.

—I believe so. I will get on to them in a moment. I thank Senator Puplick. The Democrats are going to support this legislation. I think we should remind the people of Australia that just the thought of this tax coming in is having a profound effect on the steel industry, on car production and on other things around the country, as well as on small businesses due to these seminars which the Taxation Office is having to hold-and I congratulate it for this-because of the complexity of the thing. It sent out a book, and as Senator Watson told me earlier, the book is not correct. It is out of date. It has 15 corrections, some of which are quite sizable corrections. If a person did not make the corrections, his or her calculations would not be right at all. I should finish by quoting from this letter that the Australian Parents Council Incorporated has been good enough to send me. It goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Examples of school functions at which suppers and other meals are served and at which teachers must be present are: parent/teacher nights, concerts, prize givings, committee meetings, end of year activities, excursions, fetes and other well-known and accepted school activities designed to provide better education for children.
I would bet that a lot of the teachers would love not to have to go to all those things, but it is a requirement of their employment, and now the schools are going to have to pay tax on it--

TALK.START.PARA: —It will put higher fees on the parents.
—Higher fees will obviously be coming in. Then we get on to boarding schools. The letter says:

SPEECH.PARA: Boarding schools will also be taxed for the provision of accommodation to critically important live-in teachers and supervisors.
Can honourable senators imagine what a school boarding house would be like if it did not have someone living there to control the children?

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—I do not want Senator Crichton-Browne to describe it. We all know that such a situation would be a disaster. This legislation is crazy. It could be brought in only by academics who have their heads in the clouds or by union urgers who do not like small business. That is about what is happening in this case. I will get on to the anti-small business attitude of this Government in just a moment. Finally, the letter says:

SPEECH.PARA: To impose such administrative burdens and taxes on non-government schools would divert scarce resources away from teaching children. It will also penalise the efforts of the parent-teacher community working for the improvement of children's education.

I think that I have read enough of that letter to indicate just how crazy this legislation is. I always choose my words very carefully-and `crazy' is the word that should be applied to the people who dreamt this stuff up. It is mad. We bring this legislation in at a time when the economic sky in Australia is falling in. Some of us have been pointing that out for quite a while. We have pointed out that Australia is more in debt than are many of the countries that many people think are badly in debt. The only way out for Australia-at last recognised by Mr Keating-is for business to improve. In particular, I refer to small business, which is the major employer of people in this country. If small business can be expanded and exports can be increased, thus reducing the cost of government services as a percentage of gross domestic product, maybe that is the way that this country can come out of the mess into which it is heading. I refer to an article a few days ago by Mr Warwick Costin headed `Depression coming unless we export more'. He does not say `recession', which I notice was mentioned in several newspapers today. He says `depression'. He says:
The dynamics of framing Australia's future budgets have swung squarely on to the fact that the nation must export to survive.
To export, we must have little businesses that produce exports. If we do not, we will go down the gurgler and become the banana republic about which we have spoken before in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only J-curve in sight.

—I think the J-curve is more like a ski slope; one goes up for a little while but then one falls in a heck of a mess at the bottom of the hill. That is the way the economy of this country is going. I think this article by Mr Costin is worthy of quoting in one other area. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's trade performance, in terms of its ranking as a world exporter, has drifted damagingly downwards-from eighth place in 1953, to 12th in 1964 and to 23rd by 1984.
During the past 20 years, the standard of living for Australians has fallen from the fifth highest in the world to about 20th.

How is that? That is a very serious situation. It is something that I am surprised to see the Australian Democrats supporting. We are up to our neck in debt in this country. We need to get business going to get out of that debt. However, the Australian Democrats are supporting this legislation which I believe quite directly will damage the economy further.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will throw people out of work.

—It certainly will. If I were a member of the Australian Labor Party-thank goodness I am not, in light of the way people are starting to wake up to this legislation-I would be hoping that it was defeated.
—How would you like to be a Democrat?

—I will not go into that because I do not have time. However, I believe that there will be a reaction in the community once all the effort and paper work necessary to comply with this tax become apparent.

SPEECH.PARA: One important point that we have to remember is that we do not need the legislation. Existing legislation could give the Australian Taxation Office perfectly adequate methods of collecting this tax if it wanted to. Therefore, it is unnecessary, as well as being burdensome. The economy is on that slide that I mentioned. Investment is down. We are in a recession. Our overseas debts are huge. Our standard of living is going down. I believe that this tax will add directly to a further economic retardation. As I mentioned a moment ago, this Government obviously has an anti-small business attitude. It likes to deal with big business and big unions. It does not want the little businesses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Big debts.

—Big debts? We will get on to that on another day. I want to know where he will spend this money. We have no guarantee that Mr Hawke will bring in those tax reductions later on. Would honourable senators trust him? I would not trust him with 10c, let alone all this tax money. We trusted him not to apply the assets test to elderly pensioners. But what has happened? He applied it. We trusted him not to bring in the capital gains tax. What did he do about that? He brought that in. I do not think we can trust him to bring in the tax cuts. It is another political promise. A political promise is something which goes in one year and out the other. I feel that that is what will happen with this political promise.

SPEECH.PARA: Why are the Bills not to guarantee the tax deductions before us today as a part of this package? Why are they not here? We know why there are not here. The Government will use any excuse it can to weasel out of those tax reductions. It is doing it already. It has put them off for three months, it will be another three months and then it will be: `Goodnight, nurse'. We will not get them. If we do not get them, the Democrats will be responsible.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a letter from the Prime Minister.

—My goodness! I can recall a Labor member once standing up in the House of Representatives saying that there were no spies in Australia, and he said: `We have a letter here from the Russian Ambassador saying so'. Do honourable senators remember that? It might even have been from the Russian capital. `We have a letter'-I ask you! I do not believe we will get those tax cuts. Before I close, I want to say that I do not think that the way to tackle this tax is the way advocated by some people. If it becomes law it is up to us to obey that law whether we like it or not. Mr Hawke has won two elections and the way to change the law is through the ballot box. I ask people who do not like this law to do what they can to get rid of this Government, this Government that is taxing us out of existence and ruining small businesses, and to get rid of it as soon as they possibly can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Townley has said, the items taxable by the fringe benefits tax are already taxed under the existing income tax legislation. However, the tax is currently difficult to collect because employers are not obliged to notify the Australian Taxation Office of fringe benefits paid to each employee. A number of people are exploiting this situation. The simplest and most effective way of solving the difficulties with the present tax is simply to amend the existing Act to require employers to enter on an employee's group certificate the value and category of fringe benefits supplied. However, it is a current fact of life that many people fail to declare the fringe benefits they receive. This is the problem that is leading to our current situation, and the failure of the Taxation Office adequately to enforce the existing tax has resulted in encouragement to many otherwise honest Australians to defraud the Taxation Office and the people of Australia. Any law which discourages honesty and which encourages dishonesty is a bad law.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats are agreed that the existing provisions for fringe benefits tax must be changed. They are also agreed that exemption of fringe benefits from taxation would only increase the temptation to dishonesty. Indeed, that is no solution. Rorts and exploitation of the tax system are rampant in tax avoidance through the fringe benefits area. Such rorts grow in value with a taxpayer's taxable income. For example, the provision of loans at minuscule rates of interest with repayment terms set so that the loan is effectively a gift is a way of increasing remuneration while avoiding completely the responsibility to pay tax on the moneys so collected. Certain large employers, such as banks, use such fringe benefits to squeeze employees and make certain that their pay and conditions are effectively lower than they otherwise would be.

Luxury houses, boats and private school education expenses are other rorts indulged in by the already wealthy to avoid taxes that are increasingly falling on pay as you earn employees. Executives of large companies are largely to blame for all these rorts, which allow them to increase their own wealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a load of rubbish. The honourable senator has not even read the Bill.

—This is not at the expense of their company, because they would probably consider that to be fraudulent, but at the expense of the Australian taxpayer; yet they accept this as being an acceptable thing. Similarly-Senator Messner should listen to this-it is the same executives of large companies, together with their overseas counterparts, who are responsible for what are probably the three largest tax avoidance rorts in Australia-transfer pricing, inter-company transfer of negative gearing deductions, and off-shore tax haven transfers of income. We have a problem of company loyalty overriding the individual's own principles, and that problem needs to be solved. By removing the temptation for such executives to be dishonest on their own behalf through the fringe benefits tax, we can free them to stand firmly on their principles to ensure that their companies do not indulge in these other horrendous rorts. If the Government is dinkum about stopping dishonest tax rorts it will move quickly to close down those rorts of big business as well as attacking individual Australians, the easy quarry.

SPEECH.PARA: The fringe benefits tax proposal establishes a new principle of taxing people who are not direct beneficiaries. I believe that this matter needs to be looked at closely. I consider this to be yet another instance of extra pressure on business, and on small business in particular.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why support it?

—I am just telling the honourable senator. If she listens to me she might find out. Small business in particular will find the extra paper work necessary to handle fringe benefits for its employees a large, and possibly unbearable, burden. The result will be that small business will increasingly move away from providing such fringe benefits and will return to the principle of rewarding employees for their work and value directly-in money. However, we must also free the wage setting and industrial and conciliation system to help small business face this change. Certain fringe benefits are, however, essential to enable employees to perform their work adequately, or to attract employees to work in places that most people would consider to be unfavourable. As the Democrats spokesman on local government, I have been particularly concerned with the effect of the new fringe benefits provisions on local government in remote areas.
—That is why you sold them out.

—I did not sell them out. If the honourable senator listens, he will see how we have actually supported them. Most of them will be happy. It is not easy to attract highly qualified people to work in such remote areas. Large centres of population, with their educational, health, recreational and social facilities, are much more attractive to people with young and growing families. Housing is often unattractive and below normal city standards, difficult to rent and very expensive to build. Relatives and aging parents may be far away, and telephone calls may be expensive. In addition, all living expenses have an added cost of transport. The sum total makes recruitment to remote areas very difficult. I believe in decentralisation, as do the Australian Democrats. We must not centralise our population by default activities such as the fringe benefits tax proposals as they were before we approached the Government and negotiated a better deal. We must not preclude rural and remote areas from gaining access to the talents of the best staff available in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just telling Senator Newman what she wants to know. I thank her for asking that question. To place the extra burden of fringe benefits taxes on houses, cars and travel expenses on local government in remote areas is currently most unrealistic. Farmers and rural businessmen are already in dire financial straits. Prices for rural commodities on export markets are tumbling and Australia's export earnings for rural commodities this year could well be halved-and this is on top of the drop already experienced. Rural dwellers can absorb no more taxes. For these reasons the Australian Democrats have persuaded the Government to incorporate into the Bill a number of such allowances for remote areas. However, the Government has not gone far enough. We asked it to exempt travel. It exempted only travel which is part of an industrial agreement. This would have left local government people who do not have such industrial agreements with their staff in a position of having to pay the new benefits. We will move in the Committee stage-and the Government will, I understand, accept these amendments-to exempt travel to a centre of population if it is a customary feature of fringe benefits for that industry in that remote area. We have achieved more through our negotiations than has the Opposition through opposition. We have actually produced a better tax.
—You are going to tax everybody for these weasel sell-outs of yours.

—Senator Puplick should listen. As well as local government in remote areas, most employers remote from towns provide housing, transport and often food for some of their employees. As the Democrats' spokesman on trade, I am conscious of the essential and largely unrecognised contribution to Australia made by our rural producers and small businesses, and also by employers in such remote areas. The Australian Democrats will therefore move amendments which will decrease the fringe benefits tax payable by such people to less than they currently pay. If members of the Opposition had studied the Bill, they would see that this matter is quite important. Currently, most farmers and small business owners pay tax on their estimated private use of cars at a rate of 20 per cent to 30 per cent of the total use of such cars.
—If they are paying already, why have this?

—That is exactly it. Amendments to the fringe benefits tax to relate estimated private use of vehicles to the total mileage they run will mean that, under the Democrats' proposals, country people whose vehicles always travel more than 40,000 kilometres, which is nothing for somebody in the country, will be able to estimate the private component of such use as only 6 per cent of total use. The actual tax they will pay will be below 3 per cent of the value of the car to them. They will therefore pay tax on their vehicle at the rate of only 6 per cent rather than the 20 per cent and 30 per cent which is presently the case-if they have been honest. Honest people will get benefits. The Democrats are offering tax cuts through this proposal to honest people, as is the Government. We are planning to move--
—And a tax imposition on every other honest person in the country.

—Does Senator Puplick support dishonest people? We plan to move an amendment to exempt from taxation housing provided to employees who are employed on a caretaker basis in hotels or who are required to live on the job. Already the Bill provides that tax will be payable on the market value of residential accommodation provided to employees. However, we have been assured that the valuation will be handled sensitively by the Australian Taxation Office.
—Do you believe the Taxation Commissioner?
—Yes, I believe the Commissioner. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from the First Assistant Commissioner.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Mr Greg Smith,
Treasurer's Office,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ISSUES

The following notes are provided as requested on various fringe benefits tax issues that you spoke to me about as having been raised in the course of discussions with the Australian Democrats and others.
Clergymen

It has been suggested that the exemption from FBT of benefits provided by a religious institution to a minister of religion will not apply if the minister calls in socially on parishioners. That is not so. The test for exemption is whether the benefit (the use of a car) is provided principally in respect of pastoral duties or other duties or activities directly related to the practice, study, teaching or propagation of religious beliefs. If that test is satisfied, as it would be in the ordinary case of a clergyman working in a parish, the occasional use of the car for other than `pastoral' pursuits would be irrelevant.

An associated matter raised by the Uniting Church is whether Lay Pastors would be treated in the same way as ordained clergy for FBT purposes. Lay Pastors may act in the place of an ordained Minister in the event of a ministerial vacancy and are otherwise appointed to assist a Minister.

As a preliminary view, we think that while acting in the place of a Minister a Lay Pastor could be regarded as a Minister pro tem. On that basis fringe benefits provided to the Lay Pastor principally in respect of pastoral duties would be exempt while the Lay Pastor continued to act in the capacity of a Minister.
Cars on rural properties

The FBT legislation specifies that while a car is garaged or kept at or near the place of residence of an employee it will be taken as being available for the private use of that employee. A car owned by a company (e.g., a family company) which operates a primary production business would thus be treated as being available for private use by an employee of the company if garaged or kept at or close to the farmhouse where the employee lives.

In such a case, however, fringe benefits tax will not be payable if the car is used only for business purposes and the employer elects the cost basis of valuation rather than the statutory formula. Log book records of business and any private mileage would need to be kept. If all trips during a day are business trips only 1 log book entry would be required for the day.
Residential accommodation-caretakers, national trust buildings, etc.

The FBT rules specify that tax is payable on the market value of residential accommodation provided to employees. This would include persons such as caretakers of national trust buildings, lighthouse-keepers, etc. It has been proposed that national trust accommodation be exempt, on the grounds that the tax will reduce the amount available for restoration and maintenance etc. of the buildings. It has also been suggested that accommodation provided to persons who are required to live on premises as a condition of their employment (caretakers, hotel managers, lighthouse-keepers) should not be subject to FBT.

We see no merit in either proposition. The Government has resisted the comparable argument of charitable organisations that they should be exempted from the tax because it would eat into the funds available for charitable activities. (See Mr Evans' note to the Treasurer yesterday). FBT is effectively a tax on the remuneration of employees, and there is no reason in principle why the benefits of one class of employee should not bear the same tax as those of other employees. It would be difficult to give exemption to national trust bodies while holding the line on charities.

As to hotel managers, general caretakers, etc., we do not see any reason why such benefits should be exempted from FBT when it is well recognised that accommodation that goes with the job is part of such an employee's remuneration. If they were to be exempted from FBT, a clear tax advantage would be established over accommodation benefits provided to other employees which will generally be taxed on a market value basis. That advantage could not be justified.

There have been questions as to whether the market value rule will produce an unreasonably high FBT taxable value in some cases, e.g., where a manager is provided with accommodation in a luxury hotel or tourist resort. Here the yardstick for valuing the benefit is not what a casual paying guest would pay for accommodation in the hotel or resort. Our valuers would take the view that other parallels would be more appropriate to use in assessing the market value for FBT. For example the value of live-in accommodation of a manager of a city hotel may more appropriately be equated with rents for a reasonably comparable standard residential apartment in the vicinity charged to long term occupants. Any restrictive conditions imposed on the use of the premises occupied by a caretaker in say a national trust classified building would also be weighed in arriving at the market value appropriate to the benefit.
Board and quarters under rural awards

You also referred to the operation of the FBT legislation in relation to board and accommodation benefits provided to employees under the terms of an award. You mentioned that under a particular farm worker's award, board and accommodation provided by an employer to an employee is valued at $26 per week.

We are aware that under a number of awards an employer is required to provide either free board and accommodation to an employee or to pay the employee an allowance in lieu of board and accommodation.

Examples are the Federal Pastoral Industry Award and the Queensland Shearing Industry Award which set out the rates of pay for employees engaged in shearing. The Awards set the rate of pay for individual categories of employee on a `Not Found' basis, reducing the rate where meals and accommodation are provided by the employer. This reduction is the `Not Found' allowance, which represents the value of meals and accommodation and is treated as a living-away-from-home allowance. Where meals and accommodation are provided by the employer, the employment is said to be on a `Found' basis.

The current rate of `Not Found' allowance applicable in all Australian States, except for shearers and woolpressers under the Queensland Award, is understood to be $47.35 per week. Under the Queensland Award shearers and woolpressers are from 15 April 1985 entitled to a `Not Found' allowance of $81.22 per week.

The values specified in an award may be the result of many historical and other factors and do not necessarily represent the current value of the benefit. Values specified in different awards for similar kinds of benefits can also vary considerably.

Under the FBT legislation, board provided to an employee will be valued at the rate of $42 per week (less any employee contribution). That valuation will generally be concessional. In the case of non-remote accommodation, the taxable value of the benefit will be equal to the market rental value of the accommodation (less any rent paid by the employee). The market value will vary according to such factors as the size and standard of the accommodation and its location. In many cases, the market value of accommodation provided to farm workers will be quite low. If the employee concerned is living away from home, the accommodation benefit will be exempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder we have a problem when we have a government that puts forward this type of tax that we have had to patch and patch and an Opposition that yells like a load of monkeys. SPEECH.PARA: A tax on money leaving the country would discourage borrowing from overseas, would discourage imports of goods that could otherwise be made here and would discourage the flood of money being shunted in to and out of the country to meet local requirements for audit here and overseas, which completely upsets the interest rate balance. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 12 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many statutory authorities currently exist under the auspices of the Minister's Department.
(2) What are the names of these authorities.
(3) What appeal mechanisms, if any, exist for the general public to lodge a complaint against these authorities.

(4) If it is proved that any member of staff of any of these authorities is guilty of incompetence, what action, if any, could be taken by a member of the public to sue the authority for compensation; if it is not possible to sue the authority, why is that the case.

(5) How many cases concerning these authorities are currently before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and what is the delay at present between the listing of a case and its hearing before the Tribunal.
(6) If any statutory authority under the Minister's Department cannot be sued, will the Minister consider amending the relevant legislation to make this possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are five statutory authorities within the administrative arrangements for the Resources and Energy portfolio.
(2) Australian Atomic Energy Commission; Joint Coal Board; River Murray Commission; Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority; The Pipeline Authority.

The River Murray Commission is an intergovernmental authority established under the River Murray Waters Agreement (1982) between four Governments and as such is distinct from Commonwealth authorities which have direct responsibilities to the Minister for Resources and Energy. The Joint Coal Board is an authority constituted under an arrangement between the Governor-General and the Governor of New South Wales pursuant to the Coal Industry Act 1946 of the Commonwealth and the Coal Industry Act 1946 of the State of New South Wales.
(3) There are no formal appeal mechanisms incorporated in the Acts which constitute the statutory authorities or in the River Murray Waters Agreement.

Members of the public may, however, seek redress against any of the statutory authorities by way of the same channels as other Commonwealth bodies-e.g., the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and the Commonwealth Ombudsman.

(4) The Attorney-General's Department has advised that, unless an authority is statutorily protected, it is liable for the torts of servants committed in the course of their duty. Where employees acting in the course of their duty are incompetent and, as a consequence, loss is suffered by a member of the public, it will commonly be found that the act or omission which was seen as incompetent was also tortious. In the absence of a denial of liability, the negligent giving of erroneous advice is tortious where the advice is given by a person having a duty of care to one who suffers foreseeable damage as a result of reasonably relying on that advice. Many other forms of incompetence would also be tortious, but each case would need to be considered on its own facts.

With the exception of the River Murray Commission, the statutory authorities listed in part (2) of this answer are, as provided in their respective constituent Acts, either bodies corporate or (in the case of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority) a corporation sole, and capable of suing and being sued in their own names. These authorities are not statutorily protected against liability in tort.
The River Murray Commission cannot be sued, as it is not an incorporated body. A member of the public may sue the individual Commissioners of the River Murray Commission or members of its staff.
(5) None.

(6) The question of incorporating the River Murray Commission, and hence rendering it liable to be sued, was considered by the four participating Governments in 1982, but it was found impracticable to give the River Murray Commission corporate status at that time.
